reviewText:
So after playing this game for quite some time and giving it a chance by finishing it i got 2 conclusions:

1) The reviewers giving it a bad review don't have a clue what they're talking about and they don't care about the genre of the game. Probably teenagers or people hating adventure/indie games.

2) This is a great game in all aspects. I agree it's getting a little frustrating at times and it that it has its bugs, but hey, which adventure game didn't have these things?
You have to keep in mind that this is a free game (surprisingly), and it gives you the chance to spend some hours gaming happily (if you like the genre).

This game is a hybrid of adventure/indie/mystery games. And the voice acting is awesome despite the bad comments i've been seeing around. Reminds me a bit of myst combined with the craziness of stanley parable.

I strongly suggest this game if you 're into mystery/atmospheric games and like playing through a story.

---UPDATE----
I'm sorry if I offended a general group of people, certainly wasn't aiming for that.
About the teenagers part, i said probably" and what I was trying to say is that a big percent of the teenagers can't appreciate this game properly
date: hence the bad reviews about things in this game i found prety interesting and amazing. I never said this game is perfect or doesnt have problems
recommended: i just recommended it and found the devs work really good for a free indie game.\nAbout the incoherent jumbled mess of the story

reviewText:
Only If is a free first-person puzzle game. You take control of Anthony, a young man who awakens in an empty bedroom after a long night of partying with his female companion Sam. Soon Anthony is contacted through radio by an angry man named Vinnie and discovers that Sam is missing. Now Anthony has to find Sam and escape the bizarre prison that Vinnie has made for him.
Only If is a game designed to trick and toy with you. The solutions to the puzzles are surprisingly creative. You must scan the environment for clues and use different objects to complete different riddles, allowing you to progress.
The game is divided into two paths. The first path you can choose is well done. Here the game turns full in a dream-like identity.
The second path uses some stealth elements, terribly glitched switch puzzles and environments that never feel fantastic or dream-like.
To finish the whole game with both paths takes something between 2 and 3 hours.
Graphics and voice acting are good, nothing really big to complain about.
Only If has some good aspects but also some bad (second path) In my opinion it is still worth playing, it is free, so why not?

Sounds 7/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 7/10
Atmosphere 7/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
Alright so this game is called Only If.  It is a first person problem solver game, with quite abit of horror driven behind it.

Pros
-Problems in the game are cleaver
-Decent story line
-Decent voice acting for a free game
-Very good graphics at parts in the game like when you are outside
-Horror elements sometimes that drive the game very well
-This game does not give you much direction on probelms so solving the problems make you feel nice inside
-Indie game <3
-Has no NPCs however you still feel like you are being chased or attacked, very clever

Cons
-A few minor glitches in the game, sometimes you get stuck on stairs, and sometimes you have to re do parts because the check points werent setup to the same area
-Not complete horror (not really a con)
-Same textures in the House stage
-The game does not give you much direction on the puzzles
-Listening is very very key in this game
-There is no pause

Long and short of it, its a short download, its free, its fun

reviewText: Only If" can be seen as the video game equivalent of Tommy Wiseau's "The Room."\n\nWhen you play this you will enjoy laughing at the miserable voice acting
date: the cheap stock textures and models
hoursPlayed:
and the flagrant intellectual property and copyright abuses.

Weirdly it seems as if some money has gone into this game. Clearly some time was spent making it and people were brought on board who seemed to have half of an idea of how to implement the designers' intentions. Music's great (but mostly a rip off of the "Inception" and "Shutter Island" sounds) and there are some good attempts at animation.

Truly a polished turd but at the same time fascinating. Worth playing to say you did."

reviewText:
Wow. This was a unexpected experience. o.O

I like it, I can't believe this is free! I would have easily paid some money for it just for support because of its originality, strange puzzle system and the constant conversations between the main protagonist and the antagonist radio guy cursing each other out is freakin' funny as heck. xD

You travel through a dream like world where nothing seems real and everything changes as if you were thrown into an episode of The Twilight Zone. Your only way out is to find clues and solve puzzles in this twisted world.
Some of the puzzles in this game, when you finally figure them out are actually satisfying because you will totally facepalm yourself when you figure out what was needed to solve them. lol

This game is short and can be finished in less than an hour but it's an hour well spent and for a free game, you really can't go wrong. Give it a try and see if it doesn't get you hooked into wanting to complete it on your first run. ^ ^

reviewText:
Ok, I'm going to be straight with this game.
The graphics are well done, so are the controls. The voice acting is ok too. The storyline is quirky and ok for a short game- even if you have to wait until the end of it to understand anything.

But so much about this game irritated the hell outta me!
Ok, so I was not expecting this to be an adventure puzzle game where you can actually die a million times. That's not really the games fault, but tagging could be improved. That's not the biggy though, I started small.

The game kept failing on me! So many times I had to restart the game because it was buggy as hell. I finished the entire game (which took about 4 hours) and my steam playtime showed up as 1 minute. I also received no achievements. None. I understand that some of them got taken away but even the ones that should've showed up just for finishing the game weren't there. I figured that maybe with a 1 minute playtime on my record steam didn't realize that I had even played the game. So I played it again. I followed a walkthrough to the letter this time trying to make sure I didn't miss anything. I got 3 hours on my steam playtime and still no achievements. I hunted through Google to see if their were any fixes, and there were suggestions but none of the 'fixes' actually worked, so that was disappointing. Even if there is a fix hidden somewhere that I'm somehow missing- I'm still unimpressed that the game is broken to the point that I would have to try to find one.

On top of that, there were various bugs throughout the game, like getting stuck walking up stairs (character would just flicker halfway up) and press e to pull lever" getting stuck on my screen until level restart (as it completely stopped my ability to do anything else).

The puzzles were nearly impossibly random and abstract. If you like that sort of thing- go for it- but as a huge adventure game lover (been playing adventure games long before steam even launched) I find this terribly annoying. Most games have some sort of logic to it so you can even begin to attempt to solve the puzzles. If anyone has finished this game without using a walkthrough once I'll eat my hat.

And finally- I know I'll get flamed for this but I honestly don't care- The swearing was completely and utterly unnecessary. I know there are some games that make certain characters swear for the sake of making them appear tough
date: or gangster or whatever character they're going for... but this game has said "want a swear word? TAKE THEM ALL!" I mean come on
recommended:
there's a point where something goes beyond advancing a character or storyline and dives straight into an immature prebuscent who's discovered swear words for the first time and wants to sound "cool". And that means something coming from a 20-something year old who has grown up with swearing all their life. Sheesh.

Would I recommend this game. NOPE. Move on.



**EDIT**
Please note that achievements are not my sole reason for playing games. You can see this by the fact I rarely get 100% achievements on anything- because I don't see much point. But this is a review and I'm stating problems with the game."

reviewText:
Great ideas, but it needed better execution. Just to give an example, one time I was crawling through some reeds, clipped through to a part I wasn't supposed to be at, and got stuck. So I had to restart the level and sit through the LONNNNNNGGG cutscene. This is a game where the point is mindscrewery, so ideally the mechanics should not be causing me the most frustration. At the part with all the coulmns, I fell to my death an incredible amount of times. Not because I didn't know where to go, but because I couldn't gauge my jumps. That kind of thing irks me in a bad way.

The rest of the game irked me in a *good* way through, flinging headscratching puzzles at me with utter contempt. I enjoy beating an opponent that tells me I can't, so this was right up my alley. Good voicework too, with the actors conveying exactly who each character is, even if those characters are revealed to be rather loathesome. I will not reveal the ending, only that I thought about it for quite a while, and I immediately hunted down the end credits music for my iPod.

I guess I recommend it, especially if you like media that's constantly self-dissecting and pulling the rug out from under you. But they REALLY should have playtested it more to smooth out the rough patches. This game should not be so smug in such an unpolished state.

BTW, I definitely recommend choosing the black pawn first.

reviewText: There are no humans in this game.  Only random gunshots.  You barely know who's chasing you or where they are; all you know is you die way too quick.  Puzzles without clues, clues with no relation to the puzzles, no margin for error.  Reloading from autosaves are annoying and time-consuming. Prepare to see the same cutscene again and again and again.  Crates break way too easily - whoops, did you need that to get out of this room? Well screw you, now you're stuck in this warehouse.  Forever, most likely.\n\nI don't even care if it's free to play.  It's awful, and I can barely make out the 'good' in the story through the vile language (I mean, I like my cussing, don't get me wrong, but this guy's a bit much) and the goofy, watery premise and the 'SUDDENLY SUPERNATURAL' elements of the game.  If you're going to tell a story, tell a story.  If you're going to mess with my head, do that within the confines of the story.  No mob boss (I guess?  That's who your enemy sounds like.) can magically conjure keys and talk via radio, then is totally unable to find you when you're weakened, half passing out, and crawling on the ground.  It's either realistic or it's not, guys.  Come on.

reviewText:
(This review was done pretty much immediately after release, so things may or may not have changed since.)

I'm simply baffled by this game. I know this game is supposed to be surreal (think Stanley Parable or Kentucky Route Zero), but the game is extremely confusing and irritating to play. Walkthrough is pretty much needed, as the game doesn't give the player even an inkling of an idea when it comes to solving certain puzzles.

So you begin the game by going to a party, but your vision fades to white at the door. You wake up in a strange bed with no recollection of past events, so you set to figure out what's happened. Except you're thrown into a weird dream like world that defies logic and natural laws. And you get shouted at by a voice in a radio doing a bad Al Pacino impression.

The game looks decent enough. The game runs 60 FPS most of the time, but for some odd reason tanks to 30 and even below for no apparent reason. This kind of behavior happened in the second room of the game, but when later revisiting the room in another puzzle, the game ran at 60 FPS again. I have no idea as to why this happens, forced VSync, maybe? There seems to be only very primitive graphical controls with a handful of predetermined levels of graphical fidelity. There should be more detailed graphical options for tweaking things like texture quality, anti-aliasing, anisotropic filtering, VSync etc.

The voice acting is susceptible to very annoying changes in audio level. The two types of voices you're going to hear are the main character and a mysterious voice on the radio. The main character seems to be clearly audible most of the time, but sometimes inaudibly mumbles something for no apparent reason. While this mumbling is annoying, the radio voice is even worse. Sometimes when the radio was far away, I couldn't make sense through the low audio level, distortion and unclear voice acting, whereas scenes where the radio was closer caused some clipping. In my case it got to the point of hurting my ears at certain points, especially when the radio voice was practically in my ear. The lack of captions didn't make understanding dialogue any easier.

Controlling the character is easy enough in situations that don't require precise platforming. Unfortunately, there is some precise platforming involved in at least one section. The dimensions of how far or high the main character can jump are not really clear, and I fell to my death multiple times by either bumping my head on something or just falling short. The level layout is also very confusing, and many times I had to simply make a leap of faith to see if I could make a jump - and many times that failed. There seem to be also some invisible walls, which at least in one scenario made me think I hit a bug. The way the camera behaves can also be kind of dizzying and sickess inducing at times. Especially crouching while moving can cause some tilting (I guess roll is the correct term) that is exaggerated and very unnatural.

The worst thing about Only If is the lack of direction. As of writing this review, I've been to seven or so sections. The game gives very little to no hints at all as to what you're supposed to do. Actually, I'd go even further and say that the game even misleads you. It's difficult in a review to point out these sorts of things without spoilers, and I'd like to keep this spoiler free. I'm only going to say that the game wants the player to name a thing at one point. The game primes you by displaying some scenery associated to one thing, but then expects a completely different answer. Also, there's a button mashing sequence that, as far as I can tell, leads only to the main characters death and a level restart.

Creating an experience that is not frustratingly obscure to the player is something I expect from any game, surreal or not. The worst challenges in this game are not just stopping and thinking about all the mechanics of a puzzle, or trial and error, or even memorizing. The challenge at its worst is truly in the realm of guess the developer logic" type of "puzzling". I simply cannot recommend this game in it's current form."

reviewText:
Only If there was a Review...
I can't recommend Only If highly enough to be honest. Combine the thrill you got when you first played the portal series with the highly detailed environment of most of the latest games on the market. I'm going to try and give you a nice easy list of pros and cons to help you decide whether to download this game. And even though i love the game so much, i'll remain as unbiased as i can >:D I understand that no-one wants to really read a novel for a review, so if you quickly want to find out whether its worth it, just read the dot-point titles under each category - that should give you an idea.

Pros:
-Plot > The plot for Only If really grabs you from the start. It's quite the mystery, and im not quite sure why its been tagged horror, but it certainly does have some thriller/suspense elements to it. If i try and give you an idea to the plot, it will all end up being spoilers, so you'll just have to gve it a shot. It can get really intense at times  (a lot of running, and a lot of you getting shot at, stabbed, buried alive under a lagoon, eaten by black misty stuff, falling to your death, being crushed, being chased, being drugged, and a lot of other crazy stuff) , and you have to make sure you know the environment around you if you want to stay alive.

-Environment > The graphics in the game are equivalent to most high end paid games. There is an incredible amount of detail to the world, and you'll find yourself admiring it from the very start. Trust me. They're pretty good.

-Puzzles > There is no doubt you'll find yourself wandering about trying to figure out what on Earth is going on. My only advice is that you listen very carefully to what Vinnie is saying (the man on the radio - its...er...hard to explain). Often the puzzles come in the form of riddles, and they determine how you complete each level. Once again, people complain about not clearly knowing what to do. My response: its a PUZZLE game - that's whats meant to happen :D. Often, Vinnie will have said something that points to an object in the environment you need to interact with in a particular way. Another bit of advice, when a question is asked, you may have to TYPE out your response. As another reviewer said before - when people got stuck in portal levels, noone complained there. (Shout-out to whoever that was). You'll enjoy them, trust me :)

-Achievements > There are a few easter eggs thrown about the game, as well as some pretty funny achievements. If that's your cup of tea, you'll like this. Granted, there aren't many of them, but I guess the fact that some are so darn hard to get makes up for it.

-Voice Acting > I liked the script, and the tonations of the voices. It was clever. Some people don't agree. Up to you to decide...

-Ending > That ending....oh my..... :') Remember not to just turn off the game the moment the credits turn up - you are NOT finished....

-Price > Or lack thereof. Come on people, its freeeeeeee! Just give it a shot. If you feel you wasted a few hours of your life, feel free to leave a comment here and complain about it. I promise to probably not read it ;) But yeah, just do it. It's a decent game for $0. It would still be worth it at around $10-$15+ dollars quite frankly.

Cons:
-Vulgarity > Ok, so there is gratuitous swearing and many references. There is a lot of it. It is everywhere. I really don't recommend this for someone who's under the age of, i dunno, whatever age at which this would be inappropriate. You'll need to be fairly mature. You have been warned.

-Audio >  I found that at some points, the audio volume level would vary.Now this is fairly minor in terms of cons. But you might need to keep fiddling with your volume control at various points so that it doesn't get too soft/loud at times. But really, that should be fine.

-Instructionals > At certain points, you will learn new skills, such as the ability to pick things up, etc. The instruction for this (press ... to do ...) pops up in the middle of the screen in small letters. Now generally you will catch it, but if you're not ready for it, and you miss it - you will have a particularly hard time finishing the level. This only happened in one instance for me (which was the picking up things i mentioned earlier), but i simply went back to the last checkpoint, and then everything was fine.

-Ending > I can see how people might miss the actual ending because the credits show up. So, word of advice. Wait...

So, there you are. Make your own decision, but know that this really is a game worth playing, even if you don't like this sort of thing. Give it a shot. You've got nothing to lose. It's not even that big of a download from memory, so it won't take long to uninstall if you are dissapointed. Have fun!

-The Hitchhiker!

reviewText:
Great game! There are a lot of negative reviews but you have to understand it’s a puzzle game. You must see the game all the way through. If you get stuck there is a well written guide at (Click Here for Guide)
But only read it if you get stuck in that one particular section.

I love the voice actors and the art and the imagination that went into this game and creating the scenes is phenomenal. There is a lot of swearing so just a heads up. There are plenty of great moments where you can just marvel at awe at some of the room layouts (epically ¾ of the way to completion) There are also scary what the hell moments that keeps you on your toes.

Summary: Wonderful game, see it all the way through to completion.
---------------------------------------------

Recommendations to the developers:

Fix some of the audio to SFX / Background music ratio. There are several scenes where I want to hear some of the quiet voices and they are over powered by either music or other SFX.

Remove the button mashing scene with the “E key” It really takes away from the gameplay and seems just like another crappy trigger event.

reviewText: Is this game art, or just a bunch of Unity modelling exercises randomly thrown together? After completing the game, I'm leaning towards the latter definition. The story doesn't really make a whole lot of sense, and the puzzles, while initially pretty good, eventually devolve into mere platforming/hunt-the-switch challenges. I felt like most of the stuff in the game is just deliberate attempts to throw the player for a loop, and there's no deeper meaning or reason to anything. Is it surreal? Yes. Is that a good thing? No.

reviewText:
Edit: Steam is reporting an incorrect gameplay time.  Yes, I'm aware it looks like I didn't actually play the game.  No, I do not intend to see that it gets fixed.

Yes/No is a difficult choice to make on this title.  It's sophomoric, but it's free to play.  It's clear the author is still getting his footing, so he's not charging money and that's commendable.  I've seen far worse sold for cash in the steam store, and even then sold for cash under the guise of the Early Access moniker.

I'll get my criticisms out of the way.  It looks better in the video.  In-game, it leaves something to be desired in the details.  Also, no option for Y axis inversion, so those of us who are veterans (also known as right") are forced to struggle.  Also
date: there was no easily described method of quitting.  Again

reviewText:
The game is about some dude waking up in some bed after going to some party, then he gets swallowed by darkness (no not the emo hooker) and proceeds to save sam. Story was solid. Without spoilers Al Pacino was a ♥♥♥♥, but at the same time was a pretty chill dude.

FREE: why not try it out.  Plus it has the best achievements on steam.

So now the standard game rating:Story: 9/10 (Solid, but my only question is why couldn't Al Pacino have just told him in the first place?)
Gameplay: 7/10 (walking, hitting e, walking, button mashing, running, shooting, walking. rinse repeat. Solid but nothing too good, the story is star here.)
Presentation: 10/10 (Game runs well on just about anything, using the unity engine it ran at a constant 60FPS (on my crappy laptop from 2007) and looked good while doing it.)
Soundtrack: 9/10 (fits, is fine, but didn't make me go, O-OH YEAH, GIVE ME THE MORE NOW ALL OF IT.)
Replayability: 5/10 (you should play both the black and white pawn sides, but after that there's nothing more to come back to besides maybe the achieves.)

reviewText: It's sort of shocking, how low the metascore rating for this game is. It's Free-to-Play but I would honestly pay money to play it.  Only If is very experimental , so I guess it can be easily misunderstood (note: in the Guides section there is an in-depth explanation of the game written by the developer himself, which I highly recommend reading AFTER you play it). But I can appreciate it for what it is at the core of the very short adventure: the game itself is more about the journey rather than the destination. Portraying the concept of something over the achievement of a goal. That's what I like about it; the puzzles may seem odd by themselves but are very intuitive and creative. Rather than be guided by objectives in the corner of your screen or being reminded every few minutes of your goal, the game expects you to listen closely and be patient, then think outside the box (or inside the trash can). Sometimes it's just a matter of literally slowing down and paying attention to your surroundings.\n\nThe mechanics of the game are highly innovative, I enjoyed the use of typing out words as a direct means of communication between you and the game. But it can be frustrating in some ways too. The save feature is unique in that you have to remember the code word" for the level you last played
date: then type it on the main menu to continue. However
recommended: if you quit the game at any point mid-level
hoursPlayed: you will unfortunately have to start at the beginning. That's not a big deal though

reviewText: Do you know horror movies like Scream" or "Saw".\nIn these thrillers there are unknown psychotic personalities that try to kill you in every moment without any reason it seems. The resolution comes in the end but there stays always something mysterious ...\nNow you can experience such horror in a F2P adventure named "Only If".  The graphics are sometimes very good (architecture
recommended: water effects). In other scenes you walking through labrinths of generic wooden walls. Mostly you don't know what to do. Listen to the voice that is threaten you and read some hidden advices on walls or papers. Otherwise you must die several times to find the right way out. The story evolves two different pathways the "whitepawn" and the "blackpawn" symbolized through a chessfield. So you have to play it twice to have the "full experience".\nSome of the achievements are quite buggy. Maybe the description is not good enough.\nBut alltogether you have exciting hours of confusion and deathtraps and will hopefully save your girlfriend Sam in the end."

reviewText:
Only If is visually astounding and deserves praise for unusual and innovative story telling, and that's where praising it ends. I've never been so in love with a video game's aesthetic setting of a natural park or floating Grecian pillars or surviving a dilapidated hunting cabin while being hunted by some girl's brother and friend and then within seconds being reminded it was designed by developers that couldn't be bothered by censoring themselves even once. Only If makes no attempt what-so-ever to be light or dark about its own generated humor or violence without every swear word possible; completely ripping the player out of a situation that could have brought truly powerful immersion.

Only If brings several aspects of modern gaming into a focused setting of humor, terror, confusion, frustration, and sorrow, but never delivers with what could have been a truly astounding and hard-hitting story. The game includes rich textures and breathtaking scenery mixed with interesting in-game and pre-rendered cinematic scenes making the player forget at times the game has no price tag. The game's duration and depth, especially with the richness of dialogue casting a light on what is and what is not reality and the uncertainty with either choice, is surprisingly detailed and explores just the right length of chord for the outlets it opens. Only If forces the player to make a choice, to choose a path for sake singular survival or selfless sacrifice, but eventually fails to take itself seriously once the result of either and both these choices have been explored.

Only If is one of the hardest games to not recommend, but its overwhelming flaws destroy what could have truly been a knock-out of a first-person adventure story. It blended several modern concepts into one singular medium, with a path as survival puzzling and the other as intense platforming, fusing multiple genre together and allowing them to reign but not overstay their welcome. Unfortunately, in the end, Only If fails to show restraint with its own dialogue, respect for the concept of a coherent story, and a lackluster resolution that makes all the time and efforts spent seem entirely irrelevant.

reviewText:
It's very rare that an overall good game is ruined by only one or two bad design choices, unfortunately that's the case here.

It becomes clear early in the game that, for some reason, the devs thought it would be fitting to lay out clear paths to walk which do nothing but start levels over, with seemingly arbitrary paths leading to level completion.  This creates frustration that is further exacerbated by long lead ups to those confusing paths.  The result is a trail and error system that is more punishing than rewarding;  And nothing is more annoying than having to play the same sequence multiple times over when you don't know what the devs intended for you to do.

I hate to give this game a bad review, because there is genuine quality here and it's all free.  However, when stumbling blocks turn into outright roadblocks of confusion, an entire game can be ruined in an instant, which what happens here unfortunately.

reviewText:
An enjoyable 2 hour experience made with the Unity engine. The mechanics of the game may be junk, but the story is what makes the game so intriguing. You can kind of say that it's like Portal, because the characters are what makes the story here, just like in Portal.

About the mechanics though. At the start of the game, you are given a choice. You have to choose between either a black or a white pawn. Personally, i couldn't complete the game without looking at walkthroughs, cause you will end up getting stuck a lot in this game, especially the black pawn route.

When choosing the black pawn, the levels afterwards basically revolve around using QTE's, and a lot of escape sequences. The thing about those escape sequences though - you can pretty much fail them instantly if you are not doing exactly what the game wants you to do. It's kind of like those escape sequences from COD, except that there are no words of wisdom" at the end.

When choosing the white pawn

reviewText:
This game has some promise but terrible implementation of basic video game features make the game ridiculous and impossible to reccomend in its current state:

-Unusual story that immediately becomes very weird with little explanation (this may be explained but other issues are preventing me progressing further
-Inconsistent UI that sometimes says a key and the action it performs, other times merely the action, and at one point and entirely different style
-Slightly inconsistent voice acting
-Puzzles have items that appear out of nowhere for ne reason (i.e. look at the mirror where no mirror exists until the player remarks he cannot find a mirror)
-Lack of a basic save system. I mean seriously WTF! Its 2014 and a game is released, free or not, without a save system in any shape. You have to remember a code accessed by pressing ESC and then type it in in the main menu. This was the case ages ago before writeable memory was the norm but writeable memory has been the norm now for donkeys years so this is just a case of bad game design. End of.
-Main menu has terrible controls (Click to start, space to continue, ESC to quit) and no mouse controls
-No decent graphics options in any shape. Just Unity bog standard settings.
-Pause screen is just an overlay that blurs the screen and shows you the level code. Plus it too has bad controls (ESC to resume, Q to quit)
-Puzzles/Adventure game elements are just a case of finding something in a room that magically appeared
-Game gives no indication of what results in its 'fail scenarios' and simply restarts from a checkpoint with no help. Everything is just far to vague. Flailing wildy tag anyone? (This is why I gave up. I have better things to do than crawl through some bushes and then die for no reason repeatedly)

reviewText:
I saw that this game had mixed reviews before installing it but I thought I would give it a chance anyways with the hope that it was an exploration-type game, which is something I really enjoy.

Now I know why it's so mixed.

People have complained before how newer games may give too much intructions in the beginning but this seems to have the opposite issue. You don't know what your doing and the intructions given are pretty vague. Sadly I was not able to poke around at the objects like I had hoped. If you're someone who likes rummaging and touching objects like in Fallout or Skyrim this game is not for you.

The story is lackluster at best. College-age guy goes to a party and then wakes up in a bedroom having no idea what's going on. Cliche! Then some angry dude berates you over a radio which magically moves from one room to the next. The angry guy is either a mobster or a gangster depending on how you interpet his accent. No idea if he's working with the black fog or not as I gave up trying to button-mash my way through the fog to no avail.

I was hoping for something close to Going Home" but this was nothing like it. While perhaps I should have read the reviews beforehand I wanted to try a game fresh with no bais either way. This is what I got."

reviewText:
This is that one game I would feel obliged to spend some spare pennies for, I feel saddened to see this game not getting the credit it fully deserves.

I mean – for a game that is free – it boast incredible graphics which are both awe inspiring and stunning. But it wasn’t the stunning and beautiful graphics that made me feel this game really was one of the best games I have played in a long time, it was the cleverly plotted story line. Through the delusions and puzzles you will have to overcome, you will find yourself wanting to know more. Why your there and why your following orders from the delirious guy that seems to haunt the mind of the character you play. It is a truly brilliant game.

In conclusion, I felt that the game was short but I still got the same feeling anyone gets when they complete the game they been playing along time which is both success but sentiment. I also felt that getting all the achievements for the game was a really fun challenge; I wish to see more of this game. 10/10.

reviewText:
What to say about Only If..
First.
No idea what the title have to do with the game.
Personally, I couldn't find a connection.
Second.
The game. It is a problem solver, with some fairly interesting puzzles, and some completely random puzzles.
It left me with a feeling of wonder. Specifically, wondering what they were trying to do with this game.
The story is almost nonexistent, some levels don't make sense, and the antagonist gets so annoying at times, I muted the game, just to be free from him.
And yet, I still recommend the game.
Why? because in spite of its weirdness, and it is weird, it is also kinda fun.
Does it have issues? Yes, yes it does, but it is free, and only takes a couple of hours to play through, so if you don't like it, no harm done.
One word of advise. For the full (and IMO best) experience of the game, when you get the choice, pick the black one first.

reviewText:
This is beyond one of *the* worst modern games I've ever played in my life; HOWEVER, this is great if you're looking to kill some serious time and test your ability to eat knives as you attempt to play this game through all of the bugs, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ clues, and terrible direction you receive. If you think your life is bad now, just wait until you play this through to the ending. Think about how depressed and bored this game developer was to put his friends through torture to get them to voice act for it. If you think like a developer, you can easily beat this game, but if you think about the character or are new to puzzle games: good luck. You're never going to beat this game. You know those cringe compliations you see on youtube? Well skip the latest compilation video, and play this video game instead, and you'll see some of the worst voice acting you've ever heard mixed with one of the worst storylines you've ever witnessed. Consider Doom 4's storyline a work of art compared to this.

This game was recommended to me by a friend, it was 0 challenge to me personally. If you've successfully beat Antichamber this is going to seem like child's play to you.

Yes, it threw me for a curve ball and/or mind♥♥♥♥ only because it made no sense whatsoever, but I have to say, if you make it past the basement level, you deserve a medal of honor for being one of the most mentally ♥♥♥♥ed up people on the face of this planet. Like really, why have you tortured yourself to this point? It doesn't take intellect, it takes literal perserverence to continue beating yourself in the head with a hammer. I command all people who get past this point.

The white pawn level simply glitched and I passed it by doing absolutely nothing. In fact, there are AT LEAST 2 easily discoverable bugs to skip segments of this short game (outsmarting the game developers, what a surprise)...

The achievements glitched out and I couldn't get any other than the achievement that calls me a pervert (thanks for that); I'm not willing to play through this game within the next few years until I get extremely, extremely drunk. Like, next-level drunk. We're talking suicidal-drunk here, because you have to have a deathwish or perhaps a wish to throw time you have relentlessly in a garbage disposal clogged with those knives you regurgitated from earlier.

Just beyond terrible. The beginning hooks you, and makes you think the story is going to go somewhere. It won't. It will never. Go buy the Stanley Parable while it's on sale so you can finally get a breath of fresh air.

I passionately hate this game, and if you don't too, you might as well be ordained a saint for giving this game a good review. Seriously, you're one of the most kind-hearted, charitable, and honest people alive to see the goodness in this game. You're beyond a saint. You will be the next Mother Theresa if you just stopped playing video games. Go, make a positive difference in the world, and don't waste ANY more time on this whatsoever. You don't deserve such pain.

If you can deal with the gameplay mechanics, graphics, and concept/plotline behind this game, I somehow recommend that \Second Life" would be a great game for you. At least it has better voice acting.

PS: That reference to the Portal series in the beginning of the game is simply advising that you just go play Portal instead. Even the main character is dreaming he can play Portal instead of being stuck in this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

PSS: Before you remove my game review
date: please fix the ♥♥♥♥ing achievements in this game. I am NOT willing to play this thing again anytime soon

voteText: and wants you to die while playing it (and that\'s why it\'s free)."

reviewText:
Only If – Puzzle; Suspense
a spoiler-free review

Rating: Recommended


First off, this game is 100% verifiably free. Second, I am tempted to give the game a Recommended with Caution rating for absurdly horrible profanity, but the game itself is fun enough to warrant a good rating.

Only If is a game that is guaranteed to confuse you. It’s sort of like watching what a druggie experiences through their eyes; there are realistic moments, but they are the exception rather than the rule.

A brief preview: you control a man named Anthony who is invited by Sam, a girl he likes, to a party. You walk through the doors into the party house and the next thing you know, you wake up in an unfamiliar bedroom. Sam is nowhere to be found. You open the bedroom door to explore the house and are startled to see…(end of spoiler-free content).

I enjoyed this game tremendously…after I stopped raging at how many times I died. Only If is a puzzle game; there are very difficult sections. Sometimes the furniture, doors, landscape, or even walls change if you look away from them and then back. There are two story paths (White and Black) depending on which decision you make at one point. I recommend starting with the Black path as it leads directly into the White path (if you survive, of course).

Language in this game is enough to give it an M rating. Don’t go into this game expecting your virgin ears to survive. It’s mostly random, pointless profanity, but it is humorous at times.

There is literally no money barrier preventing you from picking this game up immediately. Unless you can’t stand cursing, PLAY THIS GAME! You’ll laugh, yell and be totally confused, but it’s worth it!

Not Recommended
Recommended With Caution
- Recommended
Highly Recommended
Recommended as Essential

P.S. - When you get stuck enough to rage-quit, use a walkthrough. Please don't damage yourself or any pets or furniture you may own. Couches have feelings too.

reviewText:
I wasn't so sure if I would put yes or no, because I enjoyed it but was also severely disappointed.

How do I start. Well I for one think the graphics are quite pretty, actually. The park was especially very relaxing and pleasing to the eye. The controls are quite nice. The voice acting is not bad, though not very fond of how often they throw in swear words unnecssarily. Some of the riddles are good, but I would be lying if I didn't say some were horrid.

More often than not, I solved riddles by walking around aimlessly, clicking on everything I come by until I get some sort of result. The part where you're able to get shot was frustrating as I couldn't understand what the man on the radio was asking me to do at first (don't like the way he did the accent, honestly), and because he gave me such a tiny amount of time to do it. I also was not completely aware I had to answer the questions I was asked when I was in the park, leaving me wandering around like an idiot for a long time. One of the parts I hated the most would be the place with floating pillars, where you had to do some platforming (and shoot some stuff). It was annoying trying to make all the jumps and figuring out where to go, and the gun's aim isn't very good. But all in all, the most upsetting/disappointing part for me was the ending. It just... didn't make up for everything else. If it had a much better ending, I most probably would've recommended the game. The ending is quite funny, yes, but it is definitely not as amazing as everyone makes it out to be. Quite a flop for me.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game to waste time or something not so serious to play, I guess this is the game for you. Like I said, even for a short game, I enjoyed this game a bit, but for more than half the time I did not. Good thing it was free, or I would be quite furious.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best games I've played in a long time. A wonderful commentary on the millennial generation.

Put aside everything you expect from games nowadays: I.E. good graphics, game mechanics and controls, straightforwardness. Look at it for what it is, a medium to discuss topics of our age.

The best example I can give is abstract art". If you go into an art museum expecting clean images and clear messages to the viewer
date: but end up looking at modern art all day
recommended: it will leave a sour taste in your mouth. Why? Because your preconceptions are clouding your ability to interpret the multiple layers of the image.\n\nDo not let Kevin VanOrd’s GameSpot review deter you
hoursPlayed: it is clear he is one of the people who couldn’t look past his own preconceived notions of what a game “should” or “should not” do.\n\n10/10
voteText: and worth every minute.\n"

reviewText: Reluctant thumbs up on this strange indie studio entry. Another reviewer mentioned that this game had some influences from The Stanley Parable, and I think that's the closest experience that players can find to this game. The difference for Only If is that the puzzles, such as they are, are a bit more rudimentary, or unpolished. Many solutions are hidden from the player until they explore their environment fully (sometimes even using disappearing objects or disappearing walls to do the job)\n\nOne scene in particular has the player pressing E repeatedly to keep from blacking out or falling into darkness". But the player isn't given any instructions other than that. So I spent at least 10 tries of trying to explore my environment (as the game encouraged me to do all along) and ending up running head first into a blackout. Eventually I saw that spamming the button and running straight through one particular part seemed to be the only way to succeed at the scene. I'm glad I stuck with the game

recommended: but the frustration was close to souring the whole thing for me.\n\nStory wise

reviewText: This game is more annoying than fun. It more often than not leaves you wondering what you are supposed to be doing instead of making you wonder how you are supposed to do it. Instead of having creative puzzles, it either has Vinnie say something vague or has vague text pop up on the screen. You then take this information and try to figure out what you are supposed to do. Collect something? Type something? Go somewhere? Who knows? Oh, times up, start over. Every time you start over it gives you a hint of what to do or just blatantly says what you need to do. Then there's the lame jumping  sections.\n\nThis game either gives you a puzzle that you have to solve by brute force or it gives you a puzzle then immediately tells you the answer. All that's left for you do to is run around aimlessly or figure out what specific thing it wants you to do to give it the answer it already provided you. The voices are annoying. The dialog is annoying. The gameplay" is annoying. The game is free and I don't think it was worth the price."

reviewText:
Even though the game is free to play it's still not worth the time you will waste to download it.

You'll find yourself dying over and over again without any explanation just to watch the same cutscenes and do the same repetitive tasks a hundred times. In the end it'll feel like a trial and error game with some actually good puzzles throw into it. But unfortunately those puzzles are surrounded by bad game design choices, taking away any fun you could have with them.

... And let's be honest here, you just want to play this game because it's free and you want those silly looking achievements, don't you?
Too bad. They are not worth it.

reviewText:
After a night of partying at some small house, you wake up to find yourself in a lavish bedroom. Its a beautiful room with a few remnants of the party left over. There's an out of place poster on the wall of an Anime girl with pink looking out for you, reaching out to you. That's only the first of many strange things you'll go through.

From there, you open the door beside the poster and enter a dark room with a sparkling crystal blue sphere that leads you through a maze, lighting up black walls with a  blue hue. At the end of the brief maze, there's what looks like a doorway. You ram the door over and over again until the door falls off the hinges and you tumble through to the next room. When you stand up, you realize its not a door, but someone had used an expensive bassinet to keep you in and you have just toppled it.

There you are, standing in a gorgeous office with fancy chairs, a sofa, wood trim, plants and several cherry wood shelves. Outside the window there's nothing but clouds and a blue sky. There's no ground. Does this mean you're dreaming or does it mean that you're in some sort of purgatory.

That's when you hear a voice yelling at you, Get outta my house before I call the cops!" You're disoriented and have no idea what's going on. The voice commands you to look into a mirror
date: but there's no mirror. After another minute there's a mirror miraculously on an unseen wall that was just vacant.\n\nThe voice orders you to look at a clock
recommended: because he tells you that you have just one minute to find a key and get out of the room. The clock has no hands on its face and its only a distraction from the real matter at hand. Finding the key. You look around the room
hoursPlayed: there's no key. Soon you start hearing what sounds like a plane in the distance

reviewText:
The game itself is very short but much worth your time considering the game is free.

It has many interesting challenges that, whilst challenging your puzzle skills in game, challenges the real life beliefs of our new generation.

It's interesting and has a hilarious ending, definitely worth the time involved in finishing it.

reviewText: I really like this game considering it's free. There's swearing involved, but in my opinion, it's nothing too offensive. The puzzles take time to figure out, but what's a puzzle if it doesn't make you think? the ending made me laugh, the whole playthrough was trippy and all over, but you'll understand why at the end. A lot of people criticize a lot about it, but what do you expect from a free game? To me, the graphics are good, the game mechanics is a little shoddy, but not enough to ruin the game. I loved it, I beat it in an hour, short but sweet, I personally give this a 7/10 rating. The graphics, story and game mechanics are something that could've used at least a bit more tweaking, but the difficulty and sound are great, and enough to enjoy the game as it is.

reviewText: Only If" is definitely a mixed bag in almost every respect
date:
but a bag worth checking out nonetheless.
I really do mean "mixed bag":

-The voice-acting is brilliant at certain points... but lackluster and hard to understand elsewhere.
-The dialogue is simultaneously believable
hoursPlayed:
and insightful at times... but unneccessarily coarse and confusing at other times.
-The story is littered with unique twists and turns... but alongside moments of sheer "why the hell is this in the game?"
-The visuals are gorgeous and diverse... but are also filled with glitches and bugs.
-The puzzles can be absolutely mind-bending... but are often un-challenging
voteText: sometimes bland
helpfulPercent:
and heavily reliant on paying attention to the dialogue: a definite downside in a game where there are no subtitles
-The music and sound direction are fantastic... but sometimes drown out the all-important dialogue
-The overall atmosphere is intense and surreal... but ultimately feels confused as to what it's trying to accomplish at all.
-The game is charming... but a lot of it comes from being entirely unprofessional.

I'd hesitate to call this game worth a particularly large amount of time or sum of money
votesHelpful: but it's a free game that will only take up a few hours of your time - even if you hoard achievements. As a result
votesTotal: "Only If" is definitely a game worth giving a whirl
votesFunny: even if you find out you don't like it."

reviewText: Only If was pretty great. It's also free. The puzzles were challenging enough, the sound effects were brilliant and at times the scenery was gorgeous. The only negative things I could find about the game were the dialogue being somewhat meh at times, along with the scenery ranging from gorgeous to just plain bland, and that the story could have been played out more exposing characters and more developed gameplay. For a first person puzzler though, that's free, I can't really complain because I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. Overall the game gave me an eerie sense that kept me trying to remember which level I was on so I could continue. Oh yes, and it's free. I would definitely pay money for this game...soo...get it because you don't have to.

reviewText: I dig it after the first hour or so of playing! I gave it a shot in a whim, but it's very cool. I got really into it and it really does everything it can to make you, as the player, look around and explore the game. The game creators are very purposeful when they make these puzzles. There weren't any, Oh
date: come ON! That's ridiculous. I could never have gotten that
recommended:
moments. There aren't any times when you absolutely need hints. You just have to keep with it.

The controls change a bit--it throws brand new puzzles in and give you very brief explanations through things like paintings on the walls. There are times when you really do have to just figure it out, but everything is so deliberate that I really appreciate it.

All in all, after the first couple of sit-down's to play it, I'm really enjoying it and am recommending it to friends.

reviewText:
I have absolutely no idea how I beat this game.

Despite the intended trial-error experimental design of this game, I'd appreciate if some basic things were put in the game. Like subtitles. Or having a textbox display the text you typed in the continue screen. Simple things like that.

That said, this game is extremely confusing. You're looking at 50 shades of 'how did I die' and stuff like that. I never got past the windmill. It just took way too long to load from the beginning of that level and having to get thru all those black blobs or whatever they were supposed to be and at the same time being shell shocked as well and can literally drop dead at any second there. However, with random dumb luck, I mananged to 'continue' at the part with the slot machine, no idea how I got there, just typed something random in the continue screen. And from there I managed to beat the game.

I prolly missed a good chunk of this game, no idea how large, but from what I seen, I personally think it's better from where the slot machine part was. You got really abstract puzzles and stuff, and not having to deal with long cutscenes due to dying for unknown reasons every 5 minutes. And hopefully have subtitles, too. I have no idea if it's possible for this game engine, as I'm not too familiar with it, but hopefully it's not hard to implement.

reviewText: This game surprised me. It constantly twists and turns until you are in a trance of trying to get to the next objective. By the time I reached the park it honestly felt like a dream. Relatively inspired, although [spoilers] ultimately you come to realise the plot is entirely nonsensical (like the television series Lost) but this isn't what matters at all. For something about nothing, this game really did create depth. I am about to and see what the other six achievements I missed were and see if there is any worthwhile content to warrant a replay. Definitely worth a couple of hours of your life if you're looking for one of those surreal / unorthodox first person games with light puzzles. It's all about the experience with games like this.

reviewText:
That game was... suprisingly good.
Yeah, puzzels at times were pretty hard (I acctualy searched for some anwsers on the internet),
but the idea of the game were great.

In short, you go on the party, and wake up in the someone elses bed.
Seems (kinda) normal, but you are under efect of drugs.
You go through many areas, never knowing if there are real world,
or if they influence one.
Most of the time you are followed by narrative voice,
that seems to have control over what is happening. (Something like narrator from Stanley Parable)

I got great fun with this game and only thing i regret
is that it weren't longer.

But why am i talking, it's free, download it and see by yourself.
I wish you good fun.

reviewText:
It has a few good qualities but ultimately left me unsatisfied and feeling like I had wasted my time.

If you have a dark, twisted sense of humor or like mind altering drugs a lot you may enjoy Only If. Otherwise I can't recommend it.

The dialogue and story is what did this game in for me. Most of it is juvenile, profanity laden yelling and cryptic messages related to the game's puzzles. There are a few points where its obscurity gives the illusion of having depth. The ending, however, reveals a rotten core that could at best be called dark comedy and at worst empty, insulting and pointlessly obscene. Now, I can stomach indecent language and references (Game of Thrones comes to mind) so don't get the idea that I'm writing this negative review because the game offended me.

Compounding the problems the dialogue has are some terrible audio levels that had me constantly adjusting my volume and mediocre voice acting. There were several points where I had trouble understanding what was being said due to the music drowning out the voices or it simply wasn't spoken clearly by the actor. This is particularly bothersome when what's being spoken is important for figuring out a puzzle.

The puzzles were hit and miss. I did enjoy a few of them. Others were trial and error based or random enough to make solving them feel more like chance than anything clever that I did.

I was impressed with the visuals for a free game. It lacks depth in detail but still manages to be mostly pleasing to the eye. The music is also a plus.

reviewText:
I haven't gotten to the end yet, so I'm not sure if the ending is worth a change in my review. I'll edit this review when I get to the end, but for now I have to comment on this title's bizarre gameplay.
Other negative reviewers have basically taken the words out of my mouth... It's certainly not an intuitive game, it's difficult to manuever in and more times than not, it is frustrating instead of enjoyable. Trust me, I really tried to like this game. I would tell myself that the fun was in the exploration, and to an extent, it is. This game is gorgeous. If you accepted the notion that you weren't going to have much success in completing the tasks, you could enjoy it. But one can only do that for so long and for all this game's faults, it's very suspenseful, and you'll be frustrated by your lack of progression.
I've played a number of games where the game leaves very cryptic clues and you have to figure out what to do next. If you don't like these games, you'll absolutely hate this one, because it's even more cryptic than most. The clues disappear (such as in the room with the bowl you drink from, the paintings turn into verbal clues, but only for a few seconds) or sometimes leave you searching for a long time, or perhaps if you don't follow the directions exactly so, you'll misstep and lose your direction entirely. I barely had the patience for it, and I was interested in the storyline! If the storyline seems too pretentious or you just don't care for it, you won't enjoy this game.

Pros:
-Beautiful graphics
-Suspenseful/compelling story
-Sometimes makes you think (a little)

Cons:
-Jittery camera
-Cryptic clues
-Excessive/nonsensical swearing (And I love to ♥♥♥♥ing swear!)
-Weird audio effects (hint: don't be too far from the radio or you won't be able to hear it anymore)
-Achievements don't work

Basically, if you like pretty graphics or maybe want to think a little out of the box, this game might be good for you. But there are other games that can accomplish this without being so broken. Instead, how about watching a decent walkthrough?

reviewText:
As long as you don't choose the Black Pawn Scenario you will be ok! Sit down, get something to drink and enjoy the trash talking and torturing. Only if is a short free to play game with an humorous, interesting and completely unpredictable story. It has a deeper message and two possible endings with puzzles along the way. The voice acting is so amazing, it feels so real like you were actually there in the room yourself.
The game may be frustrating at times. As i stated above, it has a deeper story, you may not get it the first playthrough. After finishing the game you can check the guide ''Only If Explained'' by the author of the game. Ohh almost forgot, the thing i missed the most are subtitles!

Don't forget what i told you, you really don't want to choose the black pawn!

reviewText:
Positive

+ Amazing voice acting and soundtrack.
+ Awesome characters and dialogue.
+ Crazy puzzles and situations that will make your mind spin. (in a good way)
+ One of the best endings I've ever seen in a game.
+ It's free.

Neutral

= Some may find the puzzles too hard or confusing, but there are guides for if you get stuck.
= There's a lot of heavy swearing. So if you don't like hearing the F-bomb, be warned that it has that.
= Those who like long games may find it too short.

Final Verdict

9/10
Though this game is not for everyone, I personally love it. The voice acting truly brings the characters to life, and the puzzles are a lot of fun. I wish this wasn't a free game so that I could give the creator something in return for letting me play such an awesome game.

reviewText:
You go to a party, then wake up in a bed with no idea where you are. An angry guy on a radio starts yelling at you. Then weird stuff happens.
It's mostly a puzzle game. There are no hints, maps, or anything that tells you what to do. This can cause you to get stuck for a really long time if you don't want to look up walktroughs. But it's also one of the game's charms. A really mysterious and trippy experience where you haven't got a single clue what you're doing. It's even pretty spooky at times.

It's a free game. So I'd say it's worth trying. The ending is amazing too.

Also, the achievements have memes as icons. Great for an achievement showcase. But they're kinda broken for me and I can't get them properly.

reviewText:
I did actually enjoy this game. I especially enjoyed watching my gf at the time play through and ask me all these different questions and where to go. I figured it out on my own so it was her turn. Only, she picked an opposite choice leading the game in a whole different direction which made me have to take over for her because she was getting frustrated and I didn't know what to do either.

The reason I find this fun is because that little segway of choice kind of builds a relation between you and your character. You're now afraid and alone while this mad man who is still faceless through out the WHOLE game is after you and you really don't know why until the very end. But it all leads back into the normal path anyways so that way you can actually continue through the game as if you never did that so in essence that little distraction adds to the game rather than just frustrates and makes you wanna drop it at that point.

The imagination that went into this was rather fast and the pacing was nice as well but I do have some questions as to really what the hell was going on. I'm sure there is some deeper meaning or maybe even just because hey it looks pretty awesome but a little clarity would be nice.

Overall, its free and I enjoyed it. I'm actually probably gonna play it again and let my friends have a go at it and see how they fare throught this ordeal.

reviewText:
I just... I just can't summon the words I need to describe how entertaining this was. While the game mechanics themselves are kind of slightly terrible, the dialogue, environments, dialogue, puzzles, dialogue, ambiance, and dialogue were all very fun and of a good enough quality that I didn't have a dull moment through the whole thing.

The one complaint I do have is that one of the areas in the Black Pawn Scenario is ruined by the vision blur that happens during blackout resist quick time events. Having to point your character in a certain direction with the mouse, run from some darkness, and simultaneously mash the E button while your entire screen is reduced into an incomprehensible blur is... I don't want to be mean to a free game but that amount of actions expected of the player, all at the same time, is bull pucky.

It's like... you just try to do that while your reading this. Hold down W+Shift and mash the E button with one hand while also trying to point at an icon on your desktop with your mouse while closing your eyes. Do you see how difficult that is? You're not even playing a game and it's !@#$ing insane! Nothing wrong here, great work team. See you next week when we all travel back in time and suggest to Nintendo that Skyward Sword should use motion controls for aiming Link's sword. Maybe we could make a detour and tell Rare circa 1996 that having Oddjob be shorter than all the other characters is a perfectly okay thing to do. TENOUTTATEN!

... ...

If you couldn't tell, I didn't like that part.

Everything else was spectacular though. !@#$ing impeccable.



Dear Developer's of Only If

If you update this game please do the following for the described sequence.

1. Set resisting blacking out to instead be mashing the mouse buttons
2. Reprogram the blackout visuals to only start darkening if the player fails to resist blacking out. A simple vignette would have the same overall effect.

reviewText: This little gem of a free little indie trip game was really impressive. Albeit a little short, close to everything about it was decent quality and extremely creative and aesthetically pleasing. The weird little story was pretty interesting, the ability to choose was a nice little addition, the story that i played included many thoughtful and clever challenges that were accompanied by good voice acting through a comical and abstract storyline. The only few things i saw wrong with it were 1. A little short, 2. The ending i got was a bit.. eh. 3. The gun could've fit the story a little more fluidly. But hey, it was free and only took about an hour and a half for one ending, regardless of how good it was, it is definetly worth trying. And i think it's a very cool little game with good music, clever puzzles and interactions, and interesting theme.

reviewText: This game is a trial and error game.  You explore, figure out what the next step might be and then try it.  You will fail.  One reviewer said that the level design was confusing, which is the point.  Walls appear and disappear.  What you see is not what you should expect.  The game even tells you this during the gameplay.  The same reviewer even talked about uneven audio levels.  All the dialouge comes through a radio, which is positioned in a certain location.  If you move away from it, it gets quiet.  If it is too loud, you should turn your volume down anyways.  The playable charaacter does mumble a little, but it usually has something to do with the puzzle you need to solve.  This game is one that is definitely worth the couple of hours it will take you to play it.  Yes, the acting is not top level.  Yes, the graphics are not finely polished.  Play it and look at the credits and you will understand why.  Anyways, definitely worth a play through and I would like to see another game form these guys in the future.  Another one that doesn't tell you what you need to do and when to do it.

reviewText:
Only If is a weird game.

As Anthony, you arrive at a party, hosted by your friend Sam(antha). Upon getting to the house, you become unconscious and wake up in a bedroom. No, you didn't have a great night, and you begin bantering with Vinnie, a man you'll only ever hear. As if by magic, he speaks to you via radio, and your journey begins.

Only If is a very short game, and you'll likely finish it in under two hours, but for the price (free!) it's well worth the ride. Your vision of reality will become distorted, things will happen, and your initial confusion with Vinnie eventually becomes swearing at each other. It has some interesting elements, and the puzzles are fun to complete. While not overly difficult, there is barely anything (aside from the first one) to help you, and you really are all on your own.

Creability has done a great job with Only If. The story is great (if a little bit confusing), the graphics are exceptional, and the puzzles intriguing. Even if the game required a purchase, it'd be well worth your money. But since it's free, it is most definitely worth your money.

You shan't be disappointed.

votesFunny:
in at least one case I realized it was not my fault; later I stopped playing after reaching a point where I don't know if I'm wasting my time bashing my head against a glitch or if I've just not figured out how to make the puzzle work yet).


Ocasional fast repetitive key-pressing; I almost couldn't get past certain spots because it required the same keys to be pressed over and over again extremely fast.


Password based "saving"; you need to memorize (and in some cases guess first) the level name you wanna come back to if you don't wanna start from the very beginning. Dying while playing just brings you back to an earlier point most of the time; but you ocasionally have to endure an first-person cutscene everytime at certain points.


If you don't mind all these issues

reviewText:
The jist? Anime: The Game.

The deets? White Pawn path was very lovely and surreal. Have yet to try the Black Pawn. Probably will never choose it anyway, because I'm a selfless baby....and people say don't do it. The platforming section was G O D A W F U L. Like seriously. When they say you will fail a lot, they mean the platforming. Make it easier on yourself. Choose the White Pawn path to get the minimal groan. Puzzles were okay. You have to pay attention to what Vinny says to understand the Park stage and beyond.

The only real gripe I have is that the game tries to be 2deep4u, but in the end it gives you an anime plot twist end and devolves from there. However, it, for a lack of a better phrase, remained in character. Oddly enough.

For a first game: this guy did a great job. I loved the atmosphere of the park and ammensity stages.  However lots of things could have been made better (i.e. the damn ending and platforming).  But I digress; this is the maker's vision. Gotta respect it a little (even if it is bad). For a free game, this is a good time waster if you're looking for a quick hour to jerk around. For a visual junkie (like me), this is a great example of how to catch a person's eye: lots and lots of atmospheric things.

reviewText: Wow.. this was a real 'wtf' game. The whole game is like a big mindf*ck, so if you are into that, I really recommend playing this game. It's kinda trippy and it has a lot of weird puzzles in it. To complete these levels (puzzles) you need to 'think out of the box'. Sometimes this will make the game a little too hard. I had to youtube 2 levels to figure out what to do... With all the puzzling, i completed the whole game (2 storylines) in 4 hours. The graphics aren't that great and the game gives often no information what to do. But, it is a free game! And I enjoyed playing it. Some tips for people who want to play this game: Look everywhere, dont trust on logic, use your keyboard more than only controlling your character (little spoiler, sorry), and dont worry about failing too many times in some levels, cause you will fail a lot.

reviewText:
The jist? Anime: The Game.

The deets? White Pawn path was very lovely and surreal. Have yet to try the Black Pawn. Probably will never choose it anyway, because I'm a selfless baby....and people say don't do it. The platforming section was G O D A W F U L. Like seriously. When they say you will fail a lot, they mean the platforming. Make it easier on yourself. Choose the White Pawn path to get the minimal groan. Puzzles were okay. You have to pay attention to what Vinny says to understand the Park stage and beyond.

The only real gripe I have is that the game tries to be 2deep4u, but in the end it gives you an anime plot twist end and devolves from there. However, it, for a lack of a better phrase, remained in character. Oddly enough.

For a first game: this guy did a great job. I loved the atmosphere of the park and ammensity stages.  However lots of things could have been made better (i.e. the damn ending and platforming).  But I digress; this is the maker's vision. Gotta respect it a little (even if it is bad). For a free game, this is a good time waster if you're looking for a quick hour to jerk around. For a visual junkie (like me), this is a great example of how to catch a person's eye: lots and lots of atmospheric things.

reviewText:
Well, after spending a solid 4 hours playing through the White Pawn story, I can safely say this game is worth your time.

For starters, for a game made in Unity, this game looks pretty good graphics wise. Except for one model (I.E. The player's hand.), everything looks fine. The gameplay is responsive, except for a few problems I had in a platforming segment, but everything else controls fluently and responsively. The story is very good, and I don't want to spoil anything for you, I'll just tell you that it will screw with your head. Also, one of the major problems I had with this game is that it's just a little too confusing at times. Thankfully, I only had to use a walkthrough for one particular area. Even if you do get stuck, if you wander around the level enough, you can find hints scattered in different places. You just have to find them.

For a paid game, this would hold up by today's standards, but for free, it's definitely a must play if you like puzzle based games.

reviewText: I just finished my first playthrough. Given that the game is free, it's an incredible experience. The graphics are prettty good and the sound isn't shabby. But the real magic comes with the ways this game messes with you. If you're into the adventure-puzzle game genre, this is another good game to put into the collection. It's not as complex as, for example, Myst but the surreal nature of the game lends itself to its own logic, with cleverly-placed hints appearing to help the player along. All things considered, I definitely recommend this to anybody for the experience.

reviewText:
Gets kind of frustrating at some points, however this is a hell of a lot of fun. ESPECIALLY for a free game. This is very similar to the Stanley Parable where you can take different paths that will lead to different endings. Only problem is it's very puzzly (making it more fun) so you may have to use the Steam forums once and a while to help you out. Good luck and have fun! =3

Additionally, if you enjoy getting 100% achievement progress in video games like I do, this one isn't to hard to 100% if you have yourself an achievement guide handy.

I reccomend this one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=291396653

Be sure to have this guide and use it BEFORE you begin so that you don't have to go back to get the achievements.

reviewText:
Only if....this game wasn't such a bad experience....


Okay, this took me a while to consider.   Is it good?  Is  it bad?  As soon as I lean one way, I end up leaning the other way. You wade through a bunch of crap, yet there is a pretty humorous punchline in the end. But is it all worth it?  By the end of the day, this game gave me a terrible taste in my mouth.  A pretty gross aftertaste.

Now, here's what the game's about.....wait....what IS it about?  Well...you attend a party for this girl you like.  You wake up and are soon assaulted by darkness.   Literally.   You're attacked by darkness.  You then find yourself meeting" the antagonist.  An Italian voiced radio that keeps threatening it'll kill you.  On Black Pawn path
date: the voice of this radio "Vinnie" keeps trying to explicitly murder you (with a fake ending).  White Pawn....has some weird sh*t happen and your main character doesn't learn to keep his damn mouth shut.  After some weird surreal crap happens

reviewText:
Only If is a first person puzzle game devoloped by Creability on the Unity Engine, in which you go to a birthday party with the hopes of getting it OOONNNN with your crush. You wake up in her bedroom after the party, and make an attempt to leave the house, guided by a short tempered voice on a radio.

Only If is NOT a very good game. The puzzles in the game are contrived at best and straight up broken at worst. The controls are alright when all you do is explore, but they aren't very helpful for precision platforming on flying painting or giant gold pillars.

The voice acting on the radio character is actually rather good, it has a decent amount of character, but some unrealized motivation. The main character's voice is not very good however, sounding cheesy and stilted. It doesn't help that the main character is pretty much just a horrible person, which could be used as a charcter study, or even a simple moral, but all it builds up to is a frankly weak ending that's comepletely irrelevant to the themes already presented.

The whole gimick of Only If is that the world can change around you as you solve puzzles. And this is alright, but it's never really used to make intersting puzzles, the creators instead care more about confusing the player. I will admit that the puzzles tend to have an atmosphere of oddity that I assume the creators were going for. The ways things play out usually is pretty intersting, leaving me quiet for most of the gameplay. But that doesn't excuse how broken the rest of the execution is!

Overall, Only If is an unplayable game. It has some interesting ideas that never go anywhere, unused potential that could have been great, and shoddily done voice acting. But hey, at least the games pretty to look at.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm usually very open to artistic approach in games, and I use to find enjoyment where others don't.\nThe problem with this title is that it tries too hard to be something, anything at all. You can really see through it cracks that is was a project of experimentation, without clear goals. Environments and scenery -gorgeous as some of them are- are a clear example of disjointness. It almost feel like stock models (the ones that come as example with your 3D modelling software) thrown together in hope that they may blend or make sense. A rather clever joke ties this nonsense, but I wouldn't call that a story, not even writing of any sort. Puzzles are frustrating and illogical, and gameplay somewhat buggy.\nSo no, I wouldn't recommend this one even though it's free.

reviewText: I couldn't even finish it. The game mechanics were choppy and the storyline a little confusing. The sound is all over the place with zero subtitles which sucks because the clues to riddles are given over a radio. The dialouge is unispired with way to many pop culture references for my taste. The graphics were alright and the puzzles had a nice difficulty but that alone couldn't hold my interest.\n\nOn top of everything there is zero instruction on what to do when you first enter the game. You are thrown into the world with zero help and you have to guess based on your experience with pervious games of this type. Most of the time you have no clue if your solving a puzzle or moving to another location with little time to react. There are parts in the game where you die" simply because you had no idea you were supposed to react to what's going on. And there is a fair amount of typing that is supposed to be going on in game but you'd never know it because again there is absolutely zero guidence in the gameplay mechanincs at all."

reviewText: If Only is a game all about a different perception on reality. This is a great idea, manifested into a great game. The art style and emotion of the game are unique, and funny (perhaps unintentionally) at times. Your choices can make the gameplay more interesting or if you choose, more bland. If you are looking for a game to just pass some time, so you can squeeze a couple of days out of something, this isn't the game for you. This game aims at giving you a deep and meticulous story driven experience that, even though can be completed in an hour or two, delivers far more than expected.
