reviewText:
This is a gem, not a really expensive one, but one that would take a serious amount out of your wallet.

Lets just get the negatives out of the way first.
1.The voice volume varies a lot, sometimes you'll need to crank it up all the way and sometimes your ears will explode.
2.The movement is a bit whack and the jumping is crap, there was one kumping puzzle that that made me rage quit becasue of the movement.
3.Some puzzles are quite vauge and others hand you te soulution (but not alot of them).

The good cometh.
1.The voice acting 8 times out of 10 is actually really good with convosations between the protagonist and antagonist quite good and some giving you a good old laugh.
2.The puzzles are varied to a degree and some are very good indeed
3.Comedy elements
4.Shooting green vases or 'pots' gives you superjump ablities that make Alex Mercer look like a preschool highjump champ.
5.The enviroments are stunning and the audio is top notch.
6.The ending to the white pawn senario is a) hilarious and b) a rough session of miderape. My face was like (0)_(0)

for a good 10 minutes.

Verdict: Why are you still reading this download it now.

reviewText: It's fun, funny, and free.\nThere's literally no reason to at least TRY this game. The puzzles are a little tough, but they're interesting enough. There's some pretty unique mechanics in here that I haven't really seen done before. It's short, and as a result I can't think of a single time where a puzzle is repeated (except once, but you can't really call it much of a puzzle and it's for the story) so I'd say it's pretty good value for the 0 dollars you've spent. There's also some anime pictures. I don't know why. Doesn't that infringe on copyright? I guess it might not matter since they aren't profiting off it, so eh, whatever. I look forward to any other games made by these guys.

reviewText:
You know what, people say this game was bad, but I personally think it was quite a good game.

It's a witty insight, much like the Stanley Parable, but the humour makes it a game of its own, I especially enjoyed the guy in the apartment and how the apartment always changed, indicating the frantic nature of the game.

The garden scene respresented how  life is like a garden, preserved only in memory. This exemplifies the witty nature of the game.

The architecture of the games structure also interested me, so much so that I used a ruler to examine the witty architecural nuances. Then I got the ruler and jammed it down my throat because the game is so awful.

reviewText:
I liked it...it was a little odd, but I liked it.  *Mild Spoilers, but no plot*








Since I completed the white pawn scenario first, then played the black pawn, I wasn't really happy that the ending required me to play the white pawn scenario again.  Because of that, when you get the choice, I suggest you choose the black pawn first.

The black scenario was FRUSTRATING.  Wandering around at the beginning unsure of what to do and constantly having to restart wasn't fun.  The house was equally so, as there were a one objective I simply couldn't accomplish without looking up how to do it.

The white scenario was awesome, however.  There was enough freedom to figure out what to do, and the puzzles only took a short amount of time to figure out.  While the two platforming sections were a little touchy, they didn't spoil the white scenario at all.

The ending...nice.  The last couple seconds seemed odd, but I'll just leave it at that.

I agree with many people about the sound issues.  I would have preferred to understand the mumbling of the main character a little better.  Some of it I could make out, but I most likely lost about half of it.  For going through all the trouble of having (almost) 100% voiceovers, I feel we should have had the option to get everything recorded for the effort put it.

Graphics were above average, and I didn't have any problems with the controls.

I don't feel like the game deserved the 39% that critics gave it.  I believe that for this being an indie game, there has to be a little slack given.  I'd give this game about a 60%, since there were several spots where it would have been nice in the white scenario to hear or see the audible clues again, along with the other issues mentioned above.

Regardless, for the fact that this is a free game, this is a nice way to spend an hour or two appreciating several people's hard work.  While it's definitely not for everyone, simply playing the white scenario would get everything one honestly needs to get out of the game.

reviewText:
Anthony decided to go to a party.

Anthony must have drank an awful lot, because he's missing some time.

Anthony met Vinnie, a charismatic voice on the radio, and everything went horribly, horribly wrong.

Only If is currently available cheap as free on Steam, which is awfully nice, considering that it's easily one of the most effective mindscrew video games in history. Combining the down-the-rabbit-hole insanity of The Stanley Parable with a much, much more ambitious target, Only If is absolutely worth trying for its engaging puzzles, gripping storyline
date:
and unorthodox level design. Admittedly, it's got more than its share of snags - Creability's grasp on 3D platforming action could use a little polish, and there were some moments where my interest in experimenting was drowned out by my urge to shake the monitor and scream at it until it told me what I was doing wrong, and while the voice acting was largely some of the most human and realistic I've heard anywhere, it occasionally was so mumbled I couldn't make out a word of it (And no subtitles either! HOW IMMERSIVE!). All in all though, there's so much done excellent here that the scrappy edges you find now and again are completely forgivable.

And did I mention it's free?

For a game I'd heard nothing about and had next-to-no expectations for, Only If is an absolute masterpiece. Get it. Get it get it get. Unless you hate curse words, as there's a lot of those. Or if you hate that NPR show Wire Tap, because the characters sound almost exactly like that show's cast. But yeah, all the rest of you?

I'm waiting.

reviewText: Only If is pretty great I think. It looks nice, it is simple and in the end, I don't know why but the story is something I am going to remember, there was something about the way it played out that made me like it a lot. Overall Only If is a pretty short puzzler, but it is most defiantly worth the experience, hearing all the voiceover, seeing all the cool sights, and just getting the feel of the game is all worth the time it takes to play through it. Early on in the game the story branches into to unique paths for you to take to the finale, so you will at least get two playthroughs out of it if you really want more after the first. Only If is free, so there is no reason not to try it you might find a story you don't easily forget.

reviewText:
Do you like mystery/thriller games?

Hold on...let me rephrase that.

Do you like  difficult fps  mystery/thriller games?

At its core that is what Only If is. However, instead of being something along the lines of Amnesia in terms of being difficult and still a good game, Only If derives its difficulty from simply not being polished or clear about what to do. While part of this can be put off as adding into the mystery aspect and making the player figure out the puzzles in each level, but a couple of the levels are simply ridiculous to try and figure out without the help of a walkhrough. In addition, some of the platforming aspects of the game are slightly frustrating simply due to confusing level design such as having to jump on parts of platforms that simply look like aesthetics.

However, even with these problems, I still would recommend this game because of the experience that it provides. The story line is interesting (albiet difficult to follow at times) and really adds to the game as a whole. And even though I have pretty much bashed the gameplay, it does have its moments that makes it fun to play overall. On top of the whole thing, the achievements are all pretty simple to get and can help you improve your 100% complete rate on your profile if you are looking for that.

Overall, I recommend this game to people that don't mind less polished games with a few annoying parts and a ridiculous amount of swearing in relation to how short the game is. This game is pretty simple to complete and will probably take the majority of people somewhere around an hour or two to complete with all achievements (if you look up how to do them, since I am almost certain that you won't be getting the One Day" secret achievement by accident).

Need a better reason? It's free and not a pile of garbage like a good deal of other free games on Steam."

reviewText: Only If is a free adventure game that really plays with youre mind but will you want to play it ? In Only If you play as Anthony. One day after a party you wake up in a mansion and a man named Vinnie comunitcates with you through a radio. Hes keeping you locked up in the mansion and its up to you to escape. So how is Only If ? I enjoyed it quite a bit. Only If is like a more confusing  version of The Stanley Parable but thats not bad because Only If is quite funny too. The game lets you explore enviroments and solve puzzles which sometimes are hard and sometimes easy as pie. Only If is quite short as well with two diffrent endings to get and its all up to youre choices. The game is essiantly an exploration game with story. So now for the pros. Well writen story and funny jokes. Few Great Puzzles and FREE and the game looks great. Now for the cons. The game is quite confusing and the puzzles do get confusing later on even though theres choice making it doesnt do much. Overall The game is quite fun and it being free is just great. Check this one out. I give Only If a 7/10

reviewText:
Only If is free and for being free I guess it's not bad. The game looks alright and playes alright (for a free game) but is otherwise a simulator for beating your head against a brick wall. While one or two challenges could be described as organic most are exorcises in trial and error. Of the two paths you choose from at the begining, the Black Pawn path is the worst, which makes me wonder why the game told you to choose that path in the previous room. Described as a horror game, nothing about the game is very scary.

The two main characters (yourself and the antagonist Vinnny) made me feel like I was playing a crossover fanfiction staring  Dipper Pines from Gravity Falls and Vaas from Farcry 3. When not being hounded by Vass, Dipper is running from a non-descript cloud of black smoke. One area in particular forces you to stave off being eaten by the smoke by smashing the E key only to kill you anyway unless you have the good sense to run in the opposite direction, which was previously blocked by an impassible wall with no indication that any such thing had changed.

I've seen some people call for this game to be removed from the steam store but I don't agree with that. The game is free and you can't fail to experience a return of investment if you haven't invested anything. I still can't recommend the game however because the puzzle-solving was bad and nothing was scary and for a Puzzle Horror game that's not good. What shocked me the most about this game is actually the positive reviews as most of them are simpley Best game evar 11/10!!1!!" while describing nothing about it. Which is never a good sign."

reviewText:
A game that truly is different.  I'm not sure how else to describe it really.  Only If is a game that I, personally, have been tracking since its beta stages on GameJolt.  It's beautiful, to say the least, and each room provides its own unique flair to the experience.  The puzzles in this game do make for a decent challenge and the story itself is quite... interesting.  The player is presented with two options from the beginning that will decide how the game is going to play out.  Just be prepared for a few twists and turns.  This is certainly a wild, confusing, and fun-filled ride.

This is a game that I would highly recommend to anyone and everyone, if for no other reason than it is a beautiful adventure game for a price that you can't beat.

Rating: 9/10
voteText: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If I were to describe Only If in one sentence, I would say it's like Penumbra, Myst, Alice rolled up into a single adventure directed by the Coen Brothers.  Parts of the game are almost so abstract they seem like they're taken from Max Payne.  Although the game seems a little rough around the edges at times, the graphics are stylistic and technically competent.  Gameplay and story wise it has a few qualities that make it worth playing.  At the core of Only If exists a psychological thriller that has heart pounding moments and challenging, but not too difficult, puzzles to the mix.  Despite a seemingly serious tone, there are plenty of comedic moments and irony that add to the interest.  The game is short, around five hours, possibly more more if you find the puzzles challenging.  Some other things going for the game are solid voice acting and well-composed music.  Coming from a lesser known production team Only If is indie gold, but if you're a stickler for perfection, you might have some misgivings about the game.  If you're just looking to burn an afternoon embarking on a unique adventure, this game might be just the thing you're looking for.Overall,  I would give the game a 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
Interesting game that I wanted to explore, but it's just terribly frustrating to play with little or no direction at all. Pretty much trial and error a lot of the time, even with the hints it gives you. If you fail, you have to restart the area which is generally slow and drawn out.

Extremely frustrating game design, even when trying to follow along with a walkthrough.
The positive reviews from this game are all people that enjoyed the randomness and were shocked by the reveal... this is by no means a well designed game, and it didn't have as much thought and effort put into it that it would have you believe.

Just watch somebody else play it so you don't have to fumble around... but honestly it's not even worth it. Just play good games like Among The Sleep or The Stanley Parable instead. Those aren't free, but at least they're worth it.

reviewText: This is an exhilarating and fiendishly funny game that comes at no cost to you. Right until the end, you will have no idea what's going on. You are presented with puzzling situations that you must extricate yourself from in order to keep a mysterious and maniacal voice from shooting you. The game gives no hints on solving the puzzles, and expects you to think out-of-the-box to discover ways to solve them. Critics of this game lament that the game is not orthodox enough and lacks solid object-oriented puzzles, but they are barking up the wrong tree and/or trying to fit a square into something that requires a circle. This game is not designed to tell you a story or test your IQ by presenting challenging puzzles. This game is about having fun -- loads and loads of it. I can't believe it's a free game, and if I had had to pay ~$5 for this game, I wouldn't have regretted it.\n\nHIGHLY RECOMMENDED. 9/10.

reviewText:
One of the weirder video game experiences I've ever had.

Great visuals and a strange, yet somehow intriguing atmosphere. Some decent puzzling here and there. Controls work well and response is fluid. The game ran without a hiccup on maximun graphical settings, despite one crash.

Terribad voice acting and sampling. Seriously. If you're out there gathering input, don't use the same methods and/or actors in your vocal recordings for the next game. It really detracts from the overall experience.

For games like this, I wouldn't wanna say much about the story, as they're much more fun going in blind. I will say that I enjoyed the twist, as well as how awkward the game is in general. It gives it some character, I suppose.

Absolutely can't go wrong with the price (free). I did play it back to back following Gone Home". That experience was overall a lot more complete and much more fulfilling. I never really gave too much of a ♥♥♥♥ about what happened or to whom during this game.

You were close. Polishing up the quality of the voices
date: and using professional voice actors would have REALLY improved the experience. I would have also enjoyed more random environmental interaction instead of just what the game would allow when it wanted something from me.\n\nAll in all
recommended: not half bad. Still weirded out. Worth trying just for its uniqueness alone."

reviewText: This is an exhilarating and fiendishly funny game that comes at no cost to you. Right until the end, you will have no idea what's going on. You are presented with puzzling situations that you must extricate yourself from in order to keep a mysterious and maniacal voice from shooting you. The game gives no hints on solving the puzzles, and expects you to think out-of-the-box to discover ways to solve them. Critics of this game lament that the game is not orthodox enough and lacks solid object-oriented puzzles, but they are barking up the wrong tree and/or trying to fit a square into something that requires a circle. This game is not designed to tell you a story or test your IQ by presenting challenging puzzles. This game is about having fun -- loads and loads of it. I can't believe it's a free game, and if I had had to pay ~$5 for this game, I wouldn't have regretted it.\n\nHIGHLY RECOMMENDED. 9/10.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the weirder video game experiences I've ever had.

Great visuals and a strange, yet somehow intriguing atmosphere. Some decent puzzling here and there. Controls work well and response is fluid. The game ran without a hiccup on maximun graphical settings, despite one crash.

Terribad voice acting and sampling. Seriously. If you're out there gathering input, don't use the same methods and/or actors in your vocal recordings for the next game. It really detracts from the overall experience.

For games like this, I wouldn't wanna say much about the story, as they're much more fun going in blind. I will say that I enjoyed the twist, as well as how awkward the game is in general. It gives it some character, I suppose.

Absolutely can't go wrong with the price (free). I did play it back to back following Gone Home". That experience was overall a lot more complete and much more fulfilling. I never really gave too much of a ♥♥♥♥ about what happened or to whom during this game.

You were close. Polishing up the quality of the voices
date: and using professional voice actors would have REALLY improved the experience. I would have also enjoyed more random environmental interaction instead of just what the game would allow when it wanted something from me.\n\nAll in all
recommended: not half bad. Still weirded out. Worth trying just for its uniqueness alone."

reviewText:
Avant garbage!

One of the worst games I've ever played, period
The game is trying WAY too hard to be edgy and avant garde but ends up as a confused mess of pretentiousness.
I've played Dear Esther and I've seen how a surrealist environment can be done well, this game has none of the charm DE did.
The story is confused (My guess is a bad writer trying to be artsy.)
The gameplay is awful (At no point are you ever told what anything does beyond push c to couch")
The graphics are good but it just makes me more disappointed that everything else just flat out sucks.

Not even worth the free download."

reviewText:
Okay. So this game is free, obviously. So, you are free to try it. And you should, so you can formulate an opinion of the game yourself.

The thing is, this game has a great idea. It's very surreal with narration and dialogue playing a heavy role in the game. It reminds me much of the Stanley Parable in some ways, and then Anna" in others.

The *problem* is this game has a lousy setup with controls and gameplay. God
date: I beat it so quickly but it was so f*cking frustrating. Basically
recommended: much of the game includes button-mashing quick-time sequences
hoursPlayed: but these are botched. You can try button-mashing
voteText: which seems to always fail. Trying to time each sequence right also fails
helpfulPercent: because you have to reach a certain amount of timed hits before death. You can time it just right
votesHelpful: but the cue for the next sequence might take too long to appear
votesTotal: OR it can just be downright buggy in that it doesn't matter how you do it
votesFunny: you will fail.\n\nUnlike Stanley Parable
commentsCount: which had humor
column16: clever dialogue
column17: and no player dialogue (thus giving the player the sense he is communicating with the *vocal* narrator through his choices)
column18: this game lacks humor and clever dialogue
column19: and instead uses excessive language and sexual innuendos.\n\nWhile I am a fan of excessive language and sexual innuendos
column20: this game uses them rather crudely. They're not effective and it's like the game is trying to overdo itself with them. The player himself has dialogue
column21: which takes away part of the surreal feeling.\n\nWould I recommend it if was a paid game? No. Would I recommend it when it's free? No. Unless you have taken a serious interest in the game already
column22: I would not reccomend it."

reviewText: This is basically an indie puzzle game, built as a discoverable situation with no real guidance.  In other words, be prepared to die a lot.  You'll say What the ffffffffff" in a lot of different ways
date: a lot of different times while playing through this game.\n\nInitially
recommended: I almost gave up due to the button-mash-to-stay-alive thing that happens at the beginning and drove me a little nuts
hoursPlayed: not to mention a couple of programming objects failing to screen draw directions on occasion
voteText: but once I got beyond that
helpfulPercent: it was worth it.\n\nThis game is different
votesHelpful: weird
votesTotal: and a bit heady (bordering on moments of pretentiousness).  In a world of sameness
votesFunny: it's refreshing to see a developer take a bit of risk
commentsCount: as well as listening to and hearing feedback from the community.\n\nThe big con you'll notice is that there's a terrible variance in the DRC (dynamic range compression).  In other words
column16: it's REALLY REALLY quiet sometimes and nearly deafing at others.  I cranked the volume to catch dialog
column17: only to have the floor shake because of audio some minutes later.  Had the developer though to simulate headphones for the character
column18: it might've helped the experience quite a bit.  Especially given that the audio is intrinsic in puzzling solving and the experience.\n\nThe graphics
column19: however
column20: are pretty great considering it's free AND indie.  There are some really heavy atmospheric moments where I noticed that the music and vibe had increased my heart rate pretty effectively.  Awesomesauce.\n\nTotally worth checking out and playing through.  Don't be discouraged.  Pop on some headphones (it makes it a bit easier) and be prepared to play with the volume a little.  And make sure your "what the fffff...?" is on standby."

reviewText:
A game that makes absolutely no sense in the beginning manages to somehow not make any sense in the end.
Only If is a game that has you waking up after a night of getting drunk like a pig, followed by a maniac talking cryptic messages to you from a radio.
Sadly, not only do the maniac's lines make no sense, his voice acting is pretty bad and there are no subtitles, so in many cases you'll be wondering what he just said.
Following the bad voice acting and odd dialogue, you get platforming with floaty controls, so you might find yourself failing more times than you should.
And once you reach the ending, suffered through the nonsensible dialogue and forced yourself through the terrible platforming, you'll reach the ultimate plot twist of this game.
The girl you plowed is your relative and you performed incest while drunk.
That's it.
That's all there is to it.
Something that made a premise in the beginning that it's a 2deep4u game ends up with the twist u fukd ur relativ lol"
Can't believe I wasted my time on this."

reviewText:
This game was a lot of fun, I rate it 10/10.

The 10 Things I love about the game are

1) I laughed a lot during the game.
2) The Graphics were amazing.
3) It had an anime picture on the wall.
4) The puzzles were A LOT of fun to solve.
5) I played this game without getting bored.
6) It had a lot of insperational quotes.
7) Some parts made it feel like a horror and some were just funny stuff.
8) The Game itself is Random.
9) The entire story was awesome.
10) I would just replay the game when I am bored just to enjoy the game again.

reviewText: I happened on this while I was bored one day and figured it looked interesting so I might as well try.  A couple hours later, I had beaten the game.  What happened in between was just a completely insane plot full of bizarre puzzles and a few moments where I wanted to bash my head into my keyboard to see if it help me solve something.  I loved it, and would have gladly paid for a game like this.  It was a tad short by the standards of what we are use to in terms of popular games, but there was no fluff or anything.  I rarely play a game and finish it with such satisfaction.  It's free, so you might as well try it.  This is a weird, fantastic, insane, hilarious game.  10/10

reviewText: I didn't enjoy this game at all. The voices were annoying or inaudible. I found myself running towards the radio as the man was speaking just so I could hear the instructions. If you go too far away you cannot hear him and before you know it you have missed the clues and they are unrepeatable. It isn't like a normal adventure where things are obvious. At no point do you get any hints as to wherever an object is useable or not. This often confuses as the controls let you down. For example to get a key that is low down on a shelf you are meant to crouch. If you don't get it just right you can't pick the key up but there is no icon to tell you that you can pick it up so you often miss things due to the controls. Obviously give it a go if it is free but I am glad I didn't buy it.

reviewText:
Only If is a very surreal experience. You play as an average joe named Anthony. You were invited to a party. You get totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at said party. You wake up in a strange house, with a strange man talking to you through a radio. You wander through corridors, abandoned houses, and surreal dreamscapes. The game is very similar to the Stanley Parable gameplay-wise. Only If was constructed entirely on the Unity engine, and it is hands down the best looking game I've ever seen come out of that engine.
Only If's main downside is the lack of replayability. In the Stanley Parable, you have several interesting and varied endings that you can receive, all of which are based on your decisions made during the gameplay. In Only If, there are two endings, and the ending you get is based on one decision made fairly early into the game. I really wish the developers took a more complicated and versatile approach to the game's endings, because one of the endings is, albeit hilarious, really immature.

Overall, Only If is a very good game, and a very interesting experience for a free to play game. I recommend you give it a try.

OVERALL RATING: 8.75/10

reviewText: It's bizarre, it's a bit clunky, it might not make a whole lot of sense and the puzzles may leave you scratching your head for a bit. The more you let yourself become immersed in the game, the more you'll take from it. It is not kind, it will not coddle you. It's unfiltered and uncompromising and it's just the right flavors of raw and mute. Some bits feel like Myst, some bits feel like Amnesia, all in one queer head-trip that will leave you puzzled and uncomfortable.\n\nFor the price of free, I give it my full recommendations, but with the caveat that it's there for people that enjoy simmering in the surreal and have the patience to push or sometimes bungle through a puzzle that gives little to no explanation. Give it one evening and treat it like an abstract novella more than a whole game- if you're not likely to read strange fiction, give this one a pass.

reviewText:
8/10
First of all: Ignore the Metascore!

This is a hilarious mind♥♥♥♥ which gets too little attention.
Imagine Amnesia, any silly first-person shooter, a first-person platformer and a lot of swearing and insults thrown into a pot, stir the hell out of that mix and there you have it: One of the best free games Steam has to offer.

It might only take about 2 hours to complete the game and unlock every achievement (which shouldn't be that hard, since there are some great community guides for that), but it's really worth your time.

Trash talk, ridiculous achievements (which are great for one of your profile showcases if you're into reaction images) and partially confusing if not even pointless puzzles make this game special.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
DEAR GAME, SHUT UP FOR A SECOND AND LET ME PLAY TOO.

For a game that looks like its going to be a visually stunning and mentally intriguing exploration puzzle game, this game is a big disappointment. WAY too many incredibly long tedious cut scenes or voice overs where game play cannot continue until the dialogue has finished. You feel as though you've barely been able to do any (annoyingly slow) actions or decisions with your character before the next cut scene begins and the endless parade of nonsensical story line continues. I got frustrated incredibly quickly. and I've sat through my fair share of frustrating puzzle games.

I felt like I wasn't part of the story. Like when you're trying to tell a story and someone keeps interrupting you and talking over you. Except they keep interrupting with irrelevant ramblings and you sit patiently waiting only to find you can only talk for 20 seconds before this happens again and again and you realise not only do you not care what they have to say, you no longer even care about what you wanted to say in the first place.

Might give it another go another night, but am expecting only more frustration and boredom.

To the games credit, beautiful scenery at times and a good idea, just executed poorly.

reviewText:
This game tries to be an avant-garde experience. However, it's riddled by technical difficulties, an incomprensible story, ugly graphics and poor gameplay.

Just as an example, one chapter of the game called Windmill I had to replay several times due to a suite of problems. I didn't mash the space key fast enough to complete a quick-time event; I crawled in the wrong direction, got stuck and had to restart the chapter; I got eaten by black smoke repeatedly; the character got drunk and the vision impaired, so I accidently went off the track and stumbled around in a graphically ugly forest while being chased by a black smoke cloud.

Later you get stuck in an old wooden house, where the furniture – or the lack there of – gives a very unfinished feeling. In the house you have to complete a set of boring puzzles, while once in a while getting chased by a  strange light without a body.

There are many more strange things and problems with the game, however, I think I have already made my point. But to summarize: the game feels unfinished and unpolished, and most of all, it's not at all fun to play.

Recommended but, some remarks.
This is a mind-bender game. It's hard to figure out what to do next.
The core of the game is the story and, the continous conversation between your avatar and a voice in background.

This game would be perfect if it had sub-titles (better if translated) and, if you could slowly read the text that pops up from time to time (and then, pressing start, to continue). Texts dissapear so quickly that there is no time to get the message.
In any case, one on its kind. Not euclidian.
You will probably constantly think or say WTF?

reviewText:
An experimental video game which, to me, is a good glimpse on what the future of video games could look like.

The game is full of new and interesting ideas. Don't get too hyped though: the visuals are subpar, the storytelling terrible, and the gameplay heavily relies on thinking outside the box, which can be very frustrating (Keep a walkthrough video open somewhere, you'll very probably need it at some point or another).

That said, it's free, it's short, and some mechanisms used by Creability are very clever (e.g the keyboard interactions), which is why I would recommend it.

Not ALL the ideas are great, far from it, but the developpers tried (and succeeded) to make something different that challenges the traditionnal video games tropes, something we'll never have too much of.

reviewText:
Short, fun and free.  Pretty perfect actually.  My favorite part was a total lack of information about the mechanics, plot or really anything else about the game.  I had no idea what to expect, (except for that park, which I liked) it's been awhile since I played a game like that.

Honestly anyone who complains about this game being too hard or hard to figure out must not play many games.  If anything I thought this game held your hand way too much.  The solution for every puzzle is either told to you or you read through implicit instructions.

Seriously though, this game is free and complete and better then almost all of the betas, early access and green lit games you have to pay for.

reviewText:
Now, to get my point across I am going to be brief. This game is free and that is a major plus for it since spending money on something that is hit and miss is so very annoying. So, that really plays a part in why this game might be worth a bit of your time.

Most of the time it ends up being a bit frustrating and the voice acting is not at all good. The characters are terrible and not someone you want to like or root for. The game is interesting at first and not the worst free experimental title. The controls are very stiff and at times the main downfall when it comes to getting things done on the platforming moments.

Now, I really am interested in what these developers do next. I do want to like, Only if, more than I do. The idea of a free game that tries something new is enough for me to write about how much a game like this should be not judged so much. Then again, really don't want to just make it seem as if the game is only anything worth mentioning because of how it is free.

It is just nice to have the developers know that there is no reason to ask for money when the product is so unpolished. Yet, the fact that they are not trying to rip you off is enough for me to follow their next work and to support anything they do up until they get greedy like most indie developers do. If I had paid for this, I would be very upset. But I didn't, so I want to give them a thumbs up for not trying to fool you. Still, I really did not enjoy myself enough while playing this to justify your time being spent on it.

If you enjoy just about anything surreal, then you might find something worth liking in this. Time is not to be wasted, just like money, so if you really want to play a puzzle game that is off the wall and save some cash while doing so, then go right ahead and give it a spin. No need to really read too much into it and waste your time on reviews. It is what it is, a free surreal, puzzle game.

reviewText: It's worth checking out if you're curious about it, but I wouldn't really recommend it otherwise.\n\nThe game feels more like a proof-of-concept, like testing the development waters with some neat tricks before launching headfirst into a much more challenging project. A bunch of cool first-person puzzles and gimmicks (and I don't use that word in an insulting way here) were just sort of strung together with a really minimal narrative. The game wants to show you some cool stuff, but it's hard to get invested in the story" of it. There's a lot of banter between the fully-voiced (!) player character and the mysterious shouting man on the other end of the radio
date: but your questions are never really answered in a meaningful way. The reveal at the end is more of a punchline than a resolution.\n\nFairly early on
recommended: the game branches into two separate paths. One is more surreal
hoursPlayed: but they both have their moments.\n\nSome of the clues are confusing or easy to misinterpret. Some of the tasks have solutions that you might find by dumb luck
voteText: without even knowing what you were looking for in the first place. Some levels make it very easy to die and aren't the most forgiving about how much ground you have to retread as a result.\n\nThe visual elements are very nice
helpfulPercent: objects and environments look great. Some other games I've played recently have made me more aware of when games (like this one) make an effort to include other characters but never let you see them (I get it; human models are complicated). It becomes a problem when it's clear there are characters talking "just on the other side of this wall/door/etc" but if they walk around to your side
votesHelpful: you get killed before you can see them.\n\nIt's an interesting game to ♥♥♥♥ around with
votesTotal: but it doesn't hold up as a complete game. I want to see what this developer can make when there's a strong story at the foundation."

reviewText:
From the screenshots, the game looked pretty good. Even the video wasn't half bad. But the game was really disappointing. When not in control of the character, like at the very beginning, I got a little motion sick. The game also wasn't too obvious to were the keys are, or what you need for certain actions, which was a bit frustrating for me. I got through not even half the game when I decided to quit. This was due to the scene where the player needed to mash a certain key to continue onwards.
The graphics weren't bad(9/10).
I didn't really get the story(but then again I didn't play through to the end, so 7/10).
The only reason why I'd replay this game would be to pick another chess piece(3/10).
I would not recommend this game to others.

reviewText:
A terrible blemish on the genre of virtual experience games. This is one of those games that makes you wonder why it got through the greenlight. Ignoring the shoehorned meme achievements, the tasteless Portal reference, and the giant blown up anime picture greeting me in the first room; my biggest complaint was the dialogue.

Our two characters communicated like internet frat boys, sputtering off things you'd expect to hear from someone playing the newest Call of Duty at 5 in the morning just after midnight release. Immediately after the two characters began to communicate, I felt awkwardly uncomfortable, not just because the swell fellow on the radio couldn't go two seconds without screaming down my ear because I'm crazy and random because ART!" but also because of how my playable character reacted.
The dialogue quickly shows how awkward it is. My character didn't seem to care about the strange situation he had been thrust into
date: and then in the very next room proceeded to just start mumbling generic insults to our lovely radio guy. I felt like I was suppose to be laughing at this backtalk
recommended: but I only felt awkward and unamused by it Only a few minutes later I came to the realization I was not enjoying the experience at all.\n\nFrom what I've read
hoursPlayed: it only gets worse from there. Since I hear that the story and puzzles are what guides this game along (not it's flashy looking graphical landscapes which initially grabbed my interest) I do not see myself coming back to this game
voteText: knowing it would only grind on my patience with its incredibly unbearable dialogue and inconsistent voice acting. Even the puzzles in this game can't breath life into it for me
helpfulPercent: I can't even stand it long enough to get that far. Not worth the time to be invested in
votesHelpful: would rather play The Stanley Parable or Dear Ester."

reviewText:
This game isn't worth money, it's worth your time. And boy was it a waste.

If you make a puzzle/adventure game, the puzzles should make sense. And a wonky script mixed with bad voice acting makes figuring out what to do in tight situations a real pain in the butt. Especially when it seems like you're supposed to be paying attention and looking for some philosophical message or whatever among it all. But it's all disjointed, irrelevant, and in the end, meaningless. The first several puzzles aren't clear and don't lend any help to the player.

FIRST FAULT: HIDDEN TYPING PROMPTS

Who'd a thunk you need to TYPE stuff into this game? Because there's no way for the player to know from the interface that you sometimes have to type junk. This threw off my friend who first mentioned the game to me. It's stupid and interesting at first, but seriously, that's terrible game design.

SECOND FAULT: BAD PLATFORMING

Is your surreal adventure game going to have platforming challenges? Or mazes? Invest in a good engine. Having the player run and jump and slide in slow motion only makes them hate the adventure that much more. Especially when it involves tiny platforms that are high up.

THIRD FAULT: IRRELEVANT STORY TELLING

I thought this was a game about a guy who goes to a party. It is. Eventually. But the entirety of the game up until the last 2 minutes is too surreal to even connect to anything without getting super super deep about it. Which it isn't deep. All of the stuff Vinnie rants to you about is just drug-induced mania. And that useless information mixed in with crucial puzzle details makes the experience lousy and annoying.

FOURTH FAULT: BAD STORYTELLING

I won't spoil the ending but if you manage the patience to get there, you'll agree with me that that's not how you end this kind of game. I expected some other wishy-washy drugged-out philosophical crud, but it's even worse- a complete shift in mood and tone. And not in a tragic or pleasant way. With really innappropriate music.

OVERALL REVIEW: 2/10.

It's a playable game that I was able to finish in 2 sittings. I wanted to see the game to the end, and I was sorely disappointed from start to finish. Bad platforming mixed with incomprehensible storytelling and cryptic puzzle design make this game not worth your time, but thankfully you saved a few bucks, right?

reviewText:
DEAR GAME, SHUT UP FOR A SECOND AND LET ME PLAY TOO.

For a game that looks like its going to be a visually stunning and mentally intriguing exploration puzzle game, this game is a big disappointment. WAY too many incredibly long tedious cut scenes or voice overs where game play cannot continue until the dialogue has finished. You feel as though you've barely been able to do any (annoyingly slow) actions or decisions with your character before the next cut scene begins and the endless parade of nonsensical story line continues. I got frustrated incredibly quickly. and I've sat through my fair share of frustrating puzzle games.

I felt like I wasn't part of the story. Like when you're trying to tell a story and someone keeps interrupting you and talking over you. Except they keep interrupting with irrelevant ramblings and you sit patiently waiting only to find you can only talk for 20 seconds before this happens again and again and you realise not only do you not care what they have to say, you no longer even care about what you wanted to say in the first place.

Might give it another go another night, but am expecting only more frustration and boredom.

To the games credit, beautiful scenery at times and a good idea, just executed poorly.

reviewText:
This game is frickin' excellent and I feel like a criminal for not paying for it.

It's the kind of game that makes you question cliches and tropes in games; how puzzles are typically solved, what's normally expected of you, what you normally expect of the game and the levels, their structure. This kinda flips that on it's head. It doesn't hold your hand but it doesn't leave you hanging, either.

I imagine the negative reviews for this game come from players who prefer a much more cut-and-dry narrative. The story in Only If" is a peculiar mixture of both linear and non-linear storytelling

reviewText:
Even though it was free to play, I feel robbed by having played this game. The first few minutes of the game setup a cruel masquarade, giving the player an expectation of clever puzzle solving intertwined with interesting level design and an engrossing story. I promise that none of these elements come to fruition.

The game very quickly abandons any hopes of requiring any thinking skills after the first quarter of the game, instead forgoing any oppurtunity for player exploration and problem solving in favor of arbitrary direct instructions on how to proceed. There is no point in playing any of the levels, as the game invariably tells the player exactly how to proceed, as if to make sure they complete the story it wishes to show off, thus removing the player's satisfaction of completing the level and killing their motivation to continue.

Additionally, the game is simply not fun to play. Level design is boring and overly complicated, and the game boasts no interesting mechanics aside from the standard walk
hoursPlayed: shoot" level of interaction.\n\nAs for the story

reviewText:
Recommended but, some remarks.
This is a mind-bender game. It's hard to figure out what to do next.
The core of the game is the story and, the continous conversation between your avatar and a voice in background.
If english isn't your mother language, it can be really hard to get what they are talking about and, most of times, it's a must to understand that voice in background to get some tip or clue about what to do.
This game would be perfect if it had sub-titles (better if translated) and, if you could slowly read the text that pops up from time to time (and then, pressing start, to continue). Texts dissapear so quickly that there is no time to get the message.
In any case, one on its kind. Not euclidian.
You will probably constantly think or say WTF?

reviewText:
A game of insta-death quick-time 'puzzles', where the rules change with whatever disjointed stage it dumps you one next.  When I was thrown back to the beginning of a set piece for accidentally walking along a path too far, after 10 minutes of mashing E in order to stop a tinnitus-inducing ball of smoke from putting me back there, I just had to pack it in.  Poor execution of a half-baked idea.  Spend your time doing something else.

Recommendation:
Go play Stanley Parable. Now THERE'S a game that has something to say!

reviewText:
I love this game. It annoyed the hell out of me at times, but I did manage to finish it. The graphics are amazing, the storyline was confusing but interesting.

I needed a walkthrough at times, but that's mainly because in one of the levels I managed to go over the top of a hill when I was supposed to turn right xD then did a lap around the entirety of the map before finally restarting the level :P Aside from the rages I don't have a problem with this game, the campaign's a bit short, the challenges and fails just make it seem longer but that's probably about it. This game is extremely difficult at times, but is also really fun. I also thought the antagonist was pretty amusing xD

This game is confusing, this game is difficult, but it is a great game and if you can manage to complete it and not rage, you will most likely have fun playing this :P

I'd give this game: 8 / 10

reviewText:
If you like detailed instructions; this game is NOT for you.
If you like being told what to do; this game is NOT for you.
If you like searching for endless hours on your own; Well ONLY IF is that type of game!
If you like odd dialog delivered with empty explanations with a vag plot; this game is seriously for you!
If you like listening to people chatter endlessly with hidden riddles; ONLY IF is definitely the game!
I would like some wine and grapes while I sit and write other's frustration as I gaze at them through a one way mirror!

reviewText:
If you're a player who likes figuring things out, ignore a lot of these negative reviews. Is it buggy at times? Sure. But honestly this is one of my favorite free games. The only thing that stinks about this is you can beat it in under an hour or two and it's not worth it to replay. What I love about it is how different it is. reviewText: I may have just gotten this a few hours ago, but it's by-far one of the most unique games I've ever played. Never have you played a game, where on occasions, you type what you need to say in order to survive, including the Park episode which already has me stumped from the bizarre, manipulative settings of the world around you. It's unique, wonderful, the dialogue is EXACTLY HOW a human would talk in the same situation you were in. Anger, fear, and there's even more emotions I still have yet to discover of the main character you play as. On the lowest quality you can choose, it's very beautiful, the ear-functions are absolutely marvelous. Looking away, you can't hear well, walking away, you can't hear the antagonists voices and much other goodies. I very much recomend it, just as soon as I opened the game, I seemed to fanboy over the creation of the unique, puzzle-style selection of the games storyline. I had trouble doing the pawn sections, where you get shot, but to just to help out people in this situation, when he asks you what two bees make, actually type in the very same scenario you are in Honey". You can type in order to communicate. It's a 10/10 for me
date: never in my life have I thought about the creativity that can be put into such a marvelous game. To the creator
recommended: PLEASE make more. I am by-far convinced you are a unique company or fellow."

reviewText: Stay away. This game is free but is a complete waste of time. Right off the bat, the game lies to you. You get a launcher and the graphics will say beautiful" or "fantastic". They are not. They aren't terrible (except out in the street where you don't actually play) but they are nothing special.\n\nThe main character talks with the antagonist over the radio. They both swear a lot just because. There is something to be said for having characters talk like real people
date: but I got the feeling the writer was giggling at how edgy he was being. You get a choice with a branching path but only one is right. If you choose wrong
recommended: you go through 2 awful levels and then have to do the other path. You have to avoid an enemy that isn't actually there. If you go toward them
hoursPlayed:
you just die without ever seeing them.

The sound balance is terrible. You have to turn the volume way up to hear the voices but then the rare music or sound effects will blow out your ears.

There is no saving. The levels have names that you have to type in when you select "continue" from the main menu. You can't see what you're typing though. I hope you caught what the level name was when you quit.

Speaking of typing
voteText:
there is one point where you have to quickly type an answer. There is only one right answer based on one bit of quick dialogue despite the antagonist just before saying "anything" would suffice.

The ONLY thing I can say as a positive is one area called "Park". It actually looks good and has beautiful music.

reviewText:
Only If makes almost all the errors you'd list to avoid for a first-person puzzle game. The setting is weird and arbitrary. The controls are kludgy. Puzzles have no mechanics or scope, just an arbitrary list of actions to guess at. The antagonist doesn't earn their position. The writing is haphazard and meaningless.

There's some quality voice acting in the game, but it's not to good effect. A promising first cut for a student project or early alpha, but it's not a polished product.

Can't argue with free, though.

It's a nice physcological romp that tests both your patience and cleverness. The puzzles are simple if you think about them long enough.

reviewText: About halfway through the game the story will fork and you'll have two options: the 'White Pawn' scenario and the 'Black Pawn' scenario. The White Pawn scenario is pretty good, but the Black Pawn levels are so darkly lit that they're unplayable unless you find a torch, something which doesn't remain with you if you decide to reload your game. This made the Black Pawn scenario take hours to finish as I stumbled about using trial and error. Finally, when I did finish it, the game bugged and chose not to give me the achievement, forcing me to play through it again.\n\nAll of this said, the White Pawn scenario might be worth a playthrough, but be aware of the game's unpredictable nature when it comes to awarding achievements.

reviewText:
I've played 23 minutes until this game lost me. Stuck at Windmill level,died about four times unsure whether I was supposed to continue to die or find a different route. It's pretty linear and I kept dying from fading (And disappearing) black spheres or non existant ones? As early as the Windmill level and as linear as it is, I should've known how to progress. But I did not.

Beginning story and direction are a big drag.

I found the voice of the antagonist quite annoying and predictable. Of course, a mafia boss. His character introduction could've been to befriend you before he turns on you. I feel that would be more compelling than to insult you as you begin. That way you can build some connection, you expect a mafia boss to be a ♥♥♥♥ anyway. Black spheres maybe introduced a little more clearly early on.

Elements that break my immersion are using the same painting on the walls. The simplistic black sphere effect, light source from windows with no actual outside light source. In the beginning two balloons that line up perfectly on a grid. More attention to detail is needed otherwise it just feels like it's lazy. Intrigue us, make us question the reality of the world.

Cut scenes were a little offputting at how a gigantic half-your-size rock does not kill you nor a falling windmill.

Graphic design of title is decent. Gets the idea, could be a bit better even for a simple game. Trailer created is pretty good. I do like the rooms that were made. Decent game for something free. Would not pay in its current state.

For those who are tenacious, play on.

reviewText:
This game is really quite trippy.  I liked it.

It is meant to and will mess with your mind, just as the anatognist does to your character.    The puzzles range from rather simple to somewhat difficult.  Though with perserverance you will figure them out.

It's largely just you (Anthony) and the person who has become your nemesis (Vinny), but the interraction between the two of you (the voice acting) is really well done.

It's not a long game.   Maybe 4 or 5 hours.   However it will actually feel longer, due to the way your persception of time and space is turned around.

The graphics are pretty well done and there is some beautiful scenery (like the park).

Finally, a word of advise, as others have noted.   Choose the black pawn first.  The story flows better and some of the dialog makes more sense when you take that option first.

reviewText:
I was expecting a tender and intimate story of a man who values superficial ideas like sex and partying highly and learns to grow past them. That's what I assumed from the way Only If presented itself.

What I DIDN'T know is that this game would be a pretentious piece of sh**.

See, Only If revolves around isolating and confusing the player; and it's nonsensical story certainly attests to that. Seriously, who is Vinnie? Who is Sam? What the hell is going on?

I get that that is the point of this game, and it does succeed- but it leaves so many holes and questions behind in its story, that I personally felt unfulfilled playing it. And the undertone message is either about... us being products of our environment and having a lack of choice in anything we do? Or is it learning to step away from video games and appreciate nature? Or is it a way to delve into the mind of a misogenystic man, who has to confront what a terrible person he is? It feels like its cramming so many random artistic messages into one game, that it turns into a big mess.

It is pretty to look at, though. That's the only saving grace for the poor labyrinthine design and even worse platforming and quick-time events. Seriously. There is platforming and quick-time events in a walking simulator. And both are annoying in their own respect.

I like some elements on this game. But for the rest of the game, it feels like a college student trying to do something postmodern in a lousy attempt to create art, without having something significant to say. And I'm gonna give it a 6/10

reviewText: Only If is not a good game, it's not even a coherent, satisfiying narative experience. What Only If is a glimpse into the future of video games, where the boundaries between the strict game genres are cast aside, and new forms of storytelling are forged.\nSimilar to the vein of Gone Home, Only If tells a short story of a young man that is at the crossroad of personal, emotional changes. But the thing is that someone or something is pushing him to make a choice, forcing him to change.\nOn the plus side, the game has a delightful voiceover work, with snappy and vibrant dialogues, and for the most part it's a good-looking game considering this was made by a very small independent team with some very interesting ideas. On the negative side, the story is a mess, with a theme that was not appealling to me. While some levels look gorgeous, such as the Park" level
date: most of them are not visual stunners and aren't designed well. The game struggles to communicate with the player
recommended: it has a poor way of teaching the player the basic use of commands
hoursPlayed: or hinting them what are they supposed to do next. It shows that it's creators have an interesting vision but still lack the experience to share it with others.\nThen why am I giving Only If a thumbs up? Because behind all the things that don't work
voteText: you can feel that the guys who made it have a potential to make a great game. It's like an unknown little movie that you accidentally stumble upon
helpfulPercent: or an experimental
votesHelpful: concept album you find at the market: they are not great works of art
votesTotal: far from it actually; but they show signs that in time people who created them can make a truly stellar piece of work.\nOnly If is a glimpse into the future of games
votesFunny: where everyone can create and share interactive stories and experiences. There will be a lot of blunders and failures along the way
commentsCount: but with every such game that tries to achieve greatness
column16: we are one step closer to making the Citizen Kane of games."

reviewText: games like this make me wish that the recommend vs not recommend review setup had a third option somewhere in the middle. only if is an experience, it's definitely worth a look if you're into abstract ideas and storytelling. i enjoyed the dialogue, vinnie's insane speeches and anthony's sass were fun to listen to. but i feel like the game as a whole set out to accomplish something so much bigger than it ended up actually doing. i guess what i'm trying to say is that the game felt shallow when it had the potential to be so much deeper. what i thought was an interesting dialogue on how reality functions within a game and the lie of freedom given to a player in a universe where their every action is pre-determined in the code turned out to actually be nothing more than a warning not to take drugs. kinda disappointing

reviewText:
To be fair, I've barely begin this game, but I certainly don't think I'll be finishing it.
This game appears to aspire to be a puzzle game like Myst, but it's just frustrating. The sensitivity of the mouse is not able to be altered and leaves you wheeling around in a sickening lurch like a mad man. Bashing repetitively on space or e (when prompted) to stay alive works only half the time when prompted, leading to restart after restart when near death. The puzzles make no sense. I get that they're supposed to be surreal, but when your only hint is something about fire and still life artworks in a room with only landscapes, urns and still life arrangements of objects, there's something wrong with your dialogue script. An inability to cause repeats of these sorts of clues or to ask for hints in-game means more restarts.
And, worst of all, the method for restarting involves typing the name of the room you're in into a menu screen that accepts no typing so you have to start from the beginning with each log in.
Mostly, the lurching constant movement of the view (which cannot be altered) leaves me feeling motion sickness, which makes all of the rest of these problems impossible to overlook.

reviewText:
For a free game, this is a must play! (I don't agree with the tag horror btw. Strange and mysterious, but not frightening)

It is actually brilliant! Yes, it has some problems, but if you are willing to get pass those, the experience is great. You could always look at a walk-through if you are completely stuck, but I encourage you not to. The game is not difficult, just a little odd at times, but that is also a good thing. Don't expect the same ol... This game goes deep.

What really excels, is the music, sound and voice acting. Yes, there are some problems with the mix, making it hard to hear at times (headphones highly recommended) but I am really impressed with the overall quality, especially the music, being a composer myself. I would say that it is as good as an AAA-title in that regard, and I'm surprised there is so much fine work within a free title.

At times, the game is frustrating and confusing. You end up repeating some parts, especially the beginning. But I also believe that some of these frustrating parts are part of the game-play, not just bad design.

The puzzles in the game become an experience itself, rather than just something to complete in order to progress. It is dream-like and mysterious. I found the ending has little to do with the real message of the game, and it felt it was put there to have a sense of competion. I encourage you to find your own meaning in the game instead though. It will leave you reflectinging for a while, and it is great when I game can do that.

I wish for more games like this, where you don't know what is going on, where you are in for a fresh experience with no handholding.

reviewText:
Some would say if something is free, it doesn't matter if there are things to work on, but I disagree. A free game is a showcase of the creator's abilities and so far I'm not impressed. If the game needed feedback than a small group of beta players is better than a large community like Steam. Obviously, this affects my buying choices for future titles; I just won't buy from Creability.
The game is ruined by lack of thought at planning. What infuriates the most, and this is a very big deal, is the lack of subtitles. I can't overstate how important they are in a game that relies on character speech to play. Being hard of hearing, I find the game unplayable without a walkthrough to tell me what's being said. Subtitles are essential in a game like this.
The ability to change keys to control the characters is also quite important.

Using the walkthrough in place of being able to hear isn't ideal, since it gives away what I'm supposed to do without allowing me to work it out. This means that my thoughts on gameplay are very biased. It looks like a good game, though far too heavy on faux-wisdom, with puzzles that quite probably present a challenge without being too difficult to solve.

If you're hearing impaired or don't use WSAD key-controls, don't waste your time. There are some excellent reviews for the game, and I wish I could play it properly to see for myself why it has them.

reviewText: Obscurity is fine. Good, even. But this game takes it to a point of tediousness and frustration.\nI would have liked to experience a strange story, but listening to the same bits of dialogue and mashing the same keys ad nauseum doesn't feel like the best use of my time.\nShame. reviewText: If you're looking for a decent story to follow and something profound to reflect on, I would steer clear of this game. The writing is poor yet tries desperately to appear deeply introspective, the characters are shallow, and the ending falls into a deus ex machina to clean up it's many loose ends, yet still does a terrible job of it all-the-while. I also found it hard to sympathize with the protagonist due to his use of homophobic and sexist slurs. Don't get me wrong--I can see the value of of doing this to build character and chart growth and development (or lack there of) for the sake of the story line, so I really did withhold my judgement until the end. But upon reaching that point, I was left dissappointed and unimpressed with his 'moral repertoire'. Instead, the insults felt thrown in there without intention, which seems to normalize their usage instead of providing any context to the already suffering plot.\n\nThat being said, the graphics are impressive (especially for an inde title) and some of the puzzles were fun, though I felt like I had done them before in other games... But neither of these things were able to overcome my chagrin for the poor writing. A lot of people seem to have a 'wtf' reaction to this game, and if that is a reward in-it-of-itself you'd be interested in, then give it a try. But if you hope to find substance in this quagmire of random philosophy references and juvenile humor, you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
Okay, it wasn't as good as the Stanley parable in quality or direction but what's wrong with that?  Let none of us forget that the version of The Parable most of us know was a remake of a game that used another game's assests and one of the greatest voice actors ever. The Parable was a unique experience and it's a good sign that people are trying to recreate that experience, that's how genres are made; and i'd really love for this type of genre to be a thing.

Vinny's voice acting will stick with me forever as one of the best things i've ever experienced.

Finally a game that doesn't walk you through the same old paces and lets you really think and explore without drawing out it's time, if you figure out what you need to do you can just do it without still needing to check every corner (except when you do need to check every corner xD).

I may be seeing this game through rose colored glasses but i gained that perspective by playing the game and immersing in it so even if the quality wasn't top shelf that's kind of a moot point, they made something that i enjoyed and that far exceeds any physical flaws it might have.

There was one part that i had to look up:
on the trail at the windmill where the wall opens up behind you only while the darkness appears. They predicted my organic reaction incorrectly causing me to spend nearly 1/2 my play time going through that cut scene and atempting to find  a way out (for a while there i even thought the game might be playing with me saying you chose your life over her's so now your damned to repeat this part over and over hoping to escape" kinda like that greek story)
But other than that all the puzzles where fair
date: meaning you could figure them out by thinking "what piece of this puzzle am i missing?" and not hunting for the 19th bamboo key to the subway employees office.\n\nWell well worth the time it took me to beat it; though i wouldn’t recommend this game to nearly anyone
recommended: i still love it. This is the kind of game you go out and find not the kind of game that's on the tip of everyones tongue. Most people are not going to like this game. Others will love it. A cult following type game. There are a few things that have to come together for this game to be something you enjoy. But hats off to the developers. "Make the game you wanna play" is the feeling i got.\n\nThe game's lack of hand hold by itself are gonna have too many drowning
hoursPlayed: even though there is plenty of direction. Be willing to think and listen. This game should go down as a milestone as a test to multiple mental capacities and every part of this game can be solved (except that one thing) Your abilities are what hold you back not the game.\n\nOne last thing: Had a ton of problems with the trophies but i played it within hours of it's release and eventually they appeared when i replayed it so i'm not sure if they fixed it or what."

reviewText: If you do not make the right choice in the beginning then you will not know what is going on. That is the only reason I would not recommend this infuriating game. The devs are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that have made a nearly imposable game, but note if you like his type of game then more power to you. The only other thing that made me a little angry is there where no subtitles and I could not have the voices louder than everything else.\n\nThat was all the bad in the game, the good is the graphic are extremely nice for a free to play indie game, and the voice sound quality was nice (I should not some of the actual acting as a little bad). And it will give you a few hours of agonizing fun. Not many people will make a game that as a huge middle finger at the end while being a rage game, I would have like it a little more if the end just left you feeling unsatisfied with all the hard work you put into it. Over all because it is free you should give it a go, but be warned if you pick the wrong path from choice one you will not know what happened.

reviewText: If you lked Antichamber or even Myst, go play those. Puzzles are only solvable if you are given mechanics to learn, this game gives you nothing and expects you to magic the answer out of thin air (or the internet). Even playing this with a walkthrough up to help wasn't fun, I didn't hear any story because the dialog is too quiet and the music too loud, and there's no way to change this. There's not even a pause menu, the game carries on while you pause, so timed events that kill you will reoccur while you go to the toilet, and you'll have to try and listen to the dialog again. I'd say don't buy, but it's free, so don't install.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't know what to think. I played the game through to the end and the ending was well, awful. It was a really random non sequitur joke and then a goofy song plays and everyone slaps their knees and I'm just sat here confused and unsatisfied like I just got told the longest joke in the world and the punchline makes no sense.
For a narrative driven game, to end on such a low note is really really bad.
If you intend to play this game, don't go in to it for the plot because nothing will ever be answered, and trust me, it's not that you can't figure it out, it's that there genuinely are no answers. The developers themselves probably don't ahve an answer, and that's not a good thing.

The puzzles are ok, although some are tedious. They're enjoyable the first time, but after finding out the surreal coating of the game is a complete sham then there's not much point to them, and late in the game they get really really really REALLY tedious. You don't feel clever for solving them, you just veel like oh my god did you really just make me shoot 100 vases.

Oh yeah, and one big problem is the fact that the audio mixing is horrible. The radio is painful to listen to and, trust me, you'll hear it a lot, while hte main character himself is really quiet. Aside from that, the voice actors themselves are really unclear in what they're saying, and there's no subtitles option. It's certainly a unique game, but it's an unsatisfying one and I feel more like the unique part of it is just the developers trying to disguise that they don't know what they're doing.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If you're looking for a decent story to follow and something profound to reflect on, I would steer clear of this game. The writing is poor yet tries desperately to appear deeply introspective, the characters are shallow, and the ending falls into a deus ex machina to clean up it's many loose ends, yet still does a terrible job of it all-the-while. I also found it hard to sympathize with the protagonist due to his use of homophobic and sexist slurs. Don't get me wrong--I can see the value of of doing this to build character and chart growth and development (or lack there of) for the sake of the story line, so I really did withhold my judgement until the end. But upon reaching that point, I was left dissappointed and unimpressed with his 'moral repertoire'. Instead, the insults felt thrown in there without intention, which seems to normalize their usage instead of providing any context to the already suffering plot.\n\nThat being said, the graphics are impressive (especially for an inde title) and some of the puzzles were fun, though I felt like I had done them before in other games... But neither of these things were able to overcome my chagrin for the poor writing. A lot of people seem to have a 'wtf' reaction to this game, and if that is a reward in-it-of-itself you'd be interested in, then give it a try. But if you hope to find substance in this quagmire of random philosophy references and juvenile humor, you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
Proof that indie games, if looked at properly, can be great.

If you're a filthy casual, this game isn't for you. You won't get some sort of easy, uncomplicated, cakewalk of a game. This game challenges you and your brain, and to some people that isn't what they want in a game.

Like every genre, this game is not for everyone. Do you want a puzzling game that tests you, rather than rewarding you for doing nothing notable? Play this. If you don't, don't.

Either way, it's free! Everybody wins, right?

reviewText:
For a game that’s free to play, I must admit, I’m disappointed.

What I like: The graphics are very well done, the controls for your character are straight forward, and the voice acting okay (at best).

What I dislike: There are times where you need to type your answer using the keyboard and there is no indication that you can do this, you have figure it out for yourself.  The clues are horrendous and extremely vague, and to make matters worse, some of them are timed with little time to respond.   There is no clear hint of what you need to do or where to go, you pretty much have to wing it making this game very confusing.  Adding to the confusion, the environment changes without warning and you have no idea what causes it.

I would call this game frustrating instead of fun.

reviewText:
Review by xKraykoz [Eric]

For a game that is free to play it was really good.
-short story
-lots of jokes
-choises
-riddles
-good graphics
-achievements
-good soundtracks

The problem for me was that sometimes it was hard to understand what to do, when I missed the line or didn't hear what the person was saying because the music was too loud. So a replay or restart choise would had been good to have there.

Story it self was quite confusing, but it may just be because English is a Second language and I just didnt understand it.

If you have nothing better to do then it is a way to waste some time.

xKraykoz [Eric]

reviewText:
I would talk about this game, if there were actually a game here. You have no real control and there is next to no immersion once you start touching the disorganized and often unresponsive controls. In a nutshell, you just keep pressing E and hope this makes some progress...maybe...hopefully...if you're lucky

I want to like this game, I really do. It has great visuals, passable dialogue, and an atmospheric stream-of-consciousness form of gameplay that in other titles (i.e. the Stanley Parable and Gone Home) has been wildly successful and has helped drive player immersion. Only If could have been something memorable. It just failed to do so and failed spectacularly.

Now, I've played some lousy games (Superman 64 and 50 Cent: Bulletproof, to name a few), but this game takes the cake and eats it...mostly because, in this day and age, when even low-budget indie games are able to successfully compete with AAA titles, this is unacceptable.

The only good thing about this game" is that it was free."

reviewText: Beautiful, tripped-out, vulgar, and excessively crude. Some of the puzzles and mazes may keep you going in circles for a while. I like the old school method of loading up levels through keywords. There's a handful of easter egg style achievements you'll run into depending on how you play. Trigger Warning for some of the dialogue but would recommend for the look, feel, and novel gameplay compared to anything else I've played. — 4/5 WTFs
